title: US-China trade talks could temper tariff angst, but rivalry runs deep
content: It’s unlikely the U.S. and China can erase the tension in their geopolitical rivalry. But they can manage it. The current talks provide a key avenue.
resumen:
Representatives from the United States and China will meet for talks in Geneva on Saturday, taking the first step toward normalizing a key economic partnership. President Donald Trump appears ready to ease tensions between the world’s two biggest economies. On Friday, he posted on the Truth Social network that 80% tariffs on China “seems right.” Bloomberg reports the administration could aim to negotiate its duties on Chinese imports down to 60%, more than halving the current rate of 145%. Reports say China has drawn up a list of American products that might be exempt from its 125% tariffs.

If America’s current tariffs stayed in place, China’s economic growth rate this year could drop by as much as a third, jeopardizing millions of Chinese jobs. Chinese factory activity fell to nearly a two-year low. China’s outbound shipments to the U.S. were valued at $33 billion in April, a 21% decline from April 2024. Overall, however, there was an unexpected increase of 8.1% in China’s exports for April.

Economists expect higher prices and lower growth, with the nation possibly slipping into a period of relative stagnation coupled with inflation, a situation known as stagflation. Odds of an outright recession, in which the economy actually contracts, are also growing.

The U.S.-British trade deal announced Thursday is narrow, reducing auto and steel tariffs but keeping a 10% tariff on most British goods in place. Washington and Beijing face a much broader set of trade disputes that will take longer to iron out.

Another faction within the Trump administration wants to slow China’s growth to maintain U.S. geopolitical supremacy.

China’s goal is to lower tariffs.

A Thursday commentary in the Communist Party mouthpiece People’s Daily stated that China has stood up to the United States’ “illegal” tariffs and “blackmail” not only to defend its own interests, but also to defend “international fairness and justice.”

If they reach a deal, it most likely would be an agreement for China to take steps to reduce its trade surplus and the US to commit to a predictable level of tariffs and other restrictions for a certain period.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent testifies on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 6, 2025.

In the short term, advantage China. In 18 months, many of President Trump’s Republican allies in Congress will stand for reelection.

China has more to lose economically from an extended trade war because it sells far more to the U.S. than the U.S. sells to it. So in the long term, America probably has the advantage.

Economist Stephen Roach in his 2014 book, “Unbalanced: The Codependency of America and China.”

China needs to shift some focus and spending to services like those of other advanced economies. The pandemic, a property market collapse, and now the trade war have sapped China’s consumer confidence. China’s leadership has elevated national security to an equal footing with growth in terms of importance.

title: Trade War Shock Is Scrambling China’s Exports
content: Shipments of goods to the United States plunged by 21 percent in April, but spiked to Asia as President Trump imposed sky-high tariffs on China.
resumen:
Datos del gobierno chino publicados el viernes ofrecieron una visión de cómo la guerra comercial ya está reordenando el flujo de bienes en todo el mundo.

Las exportaciones de China aumentaron el mes pasado, impulsadas por el comercio con otros países del sudeste asiático, incluso cuando los aranceles del presidente Trump sobre los productos chinos forzaron una fuerte desaceleración en los envíos a Estados Unidos.

Dentro de China, las importaciones cayeron a medida que la demanda continuó debilitándose.

Las cifras comerciales publicadas el viernes capturan la actividad en abril, cuando las tensiones entre Estados Unidos y China se intensificaron más rápidamente de lo esperado. En una serie de medidas, el Sr. Trump elevó los aranceles sobre los productos chinos al 145 por ciento, y China respondió con gravámenes del 125 por ciento sobre los productos estadounidenses.

Como resultado, los envíos chinos a Estados Unidos se desplomaron un 21 por ciento con respecto al año anterior. Pero las exportaciones chinas a los países del sudeste asiático se dispararon un 21 por ciento.

"Esta es una señal temprana de que algo está pasando en términos de una carga frontal de la cadena de suministro", dijo Raymond Yeung, economista jefe para la Gran China de ANZ, un banco de Nueva Zelanda. "Es una redirección del comercio que ya está bien documentada".

Las exportaciones chinas a países como Vietnam y Tailandia se han disparado, dijo el Sr. Yeung, mientras que los datos sobre las importaciones de Taiwán y Corea del Sur sugirieron que las fábricas chinas estaban aprovechando una pausa de 90 días en los aranceles en los países de la región para completar los pedidos destinados a Estados Unidos.

Los envíos generales de bienes desde China en abril aumentaron un 8,1 por ciento con respecto al año anterior. Los datos mostraron la continuación de una tendencia en los últimos meses, con fábricas chinas que se apresuraron a enviar bienes a medida que la guerra comercial empeoraba. Muchos de esos bienes terminaron en algunos de los países orientados a la exportación de la Asociación de Naciones del Sudeste Asiático de 10 miembros, o ASEAN.

"Los productores nacionales han detenido la mayor parte de su producción dirigida al mercado estadounidense, pero están preparando productos para los países de la ASEAN porque es allí donde han establecido sus fábricas en preparación para esta situación", dijo Dan Wang, director del equipo de China de Eurasia Group.

En los últimos años, a medida que la economía interna de China se ha visto obstaculizada por un colapso del mercado de la vivienda, el gobierno se ha apoyado más en el envío de sus bienes al extranjero. La crisis inmobiliaria se ha extendido por el resto de la economía y ha dejado a los bancos y gobiernos locales atascados con montones de deuda, y los jóvenes han luchado con menos opciones de trabajo.

Es probable que los datos de abril den a los responsables políticos de Beijing un respiro en medio de preocupaciones más amplias sobre el impacto de la guerra comercial en las perspectivas económicas de China. Pero los economistas advierten que el desempleo podría dispararse si la disminución de los pedidos de las fábricas obliga a las empresas a despedir trabajadores. Las fábricas chinas experimentaron su mayor desaceleración mensual en más de un año en abril.

Los reguladores financieros chinos señalaron esta semana que estaban listos para intervenir para impulsar la demanda interna para capear el impacto de la guerra comercial. El banco central recortó las tasas de interés y aflojó los grifos de dinero para dirigir más dinero a la economía para alentar a las empresas y a las personas a gastar.

Scott Bessent, el secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, y Jamieson Greer, el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, se reunirán con el viceprimer ministro de China, He Lifeng, en Ginebra este fin de semana, la primera reunión formal sobre comercio desde que el Sr. Trump elevó los aranceles a los tres dígitos en abril.

title: UK-US trade deal a 'huge relief', minister says, as businesses call for more clarity
content: Darren Jones says the government "has protected jobs because of this trade deal", as shadow trade secretary Andrew Griffith calls it "disappointing".
resumen: The US and UK have agreed on a trade deal to reduce import taxes on some British cars and metals. Tariffs on cars exported to the US will be reduced from 27.5% to 10% for a quota of 100,000 UK cars. The 25% tariffs on UK steel and aluminum imported by the US are to be scrapped. For agriculture, there will be "reciprocal market access" on beef, with UK farmers given a quota for 13,000 metric tonnes of beef to export to the US, and the US granted the same. A secure supply chain for pharmaceutical products will also be created, with final details to be written up in the coming weeks. The US will have preferential access to high-quality UK aerospace components. The reciprocal tariff rate of 10% on the UK, which was announced in March, remains in place. Chancellor Rachel Reeves described it as a "good deal". Treasury Minister Darren Jones said that 150,000 jobs had been "protected". Shadow trade secretary Andrew Griffith said "overall it's quite disappointing," adding that a more "comprehensive" agreement is needed to grow the UK economy. British Airways' parent company announced it had bought 32 new Boeing planes from the US. Liam Bates, from stainless steel manufacturer Marcegaglia, said the announcement was "very significant". Farmers have also had a mixed reaction to the deal. The director general of UK Steel says the industry is still waiting to learn the exact details of yesterday's UK-US trade agreement. Rolls-Royce and Aston Martin shares jumped as details emerged. Ian McCubbine, a beef farmer in Surrey, tells BBC Radio 4’s Today programme that “we have to be careful that we are stringent about food standards.” Food standards in the UK ban imports of treated beef or chlorinated chicken - measures that will remain in place despite the deal, according to officials.

title: Currency hedging and new U.S. factories: Novo Nordisk CFO thinks Wegovy maker can outmaneuver global trade wars
content: Novo Nordisk is hedging and building its way around a global tariff war that may threaten the Wegovy maker’s plans to expand in the U.S. Karsten Munk Knudsen, Novo Nordisk’s chief financial officer, ...
resumen:
Karsten Munk Knudsen, chief financial officer of Novo Nordisk, told Fortune the company is well-placed to handle the geopolitical upheaval that rocked global business in March and April.

Novo Nordisk’s native Denmark is also locked in a tense diplomatic battle with the U.S. over the status of the territory of Greenland, which could yet bring consequences for trade between the countries.

Knudsen wouldn’t be drawn on hypothetical duties threatened by Trump in April, when he promised “major tariffs” that would be coming “very shortly” to pharmaceutical imports.

A second priority, though, is building Novo Nordisk’s U.S. infrastructure. The company already has 10,000 employees in the States, while Knudsen pointed out it had invested $24 billion in the U.S. over the last decade.

Novo Nordisk CEO Lars Fruergaard Jørgensen said on the company’s Q1 earnings call on Wednesday as he played down tariff uncertainty.

The group is constructing a $4.1 billion North Carolina plant, where it will produce its injectable Wegovy weight loss medication. Jørgensen said that a world-first oral GLP-1, submitted for approval to the FDA in early May, would also be produced in the U.S.

The drugmaker says guidance could be negatively affected by fresh tariffs.

Knudsen told Fortune, “It's not like we are totally insulated and without exposure, but I think we have a reasonable hedge for many scenarios.”

Novo Nordisk hedges between 50% and 70% of its foreign currency reserves. With U.S. sales accounting for more than half of the company’s top line, a lot of hedging attention is given to the U.S. dollar. The dollar has fallen by 8% against the Danish krone since the start of 2025.

The company expects to make a DKK 0.9 billion ($136 million) gain in 2025, largely related to its hedges on the U.S. dollar. Back in February, prior to the tariff whirlwind, the company expected to make a DKK 9 billion ($1.4 billion) loss on its hedging strategy.

Knudsen said Novo Nordisk planned to stick to its hedging strategy “with some minor tweaks.”

Novo Nordisk, with its expansion in the U.S., is one of many threatening to hasten that expansion if EU policymakers fail to undergo a regulatory and intellectual property overhaul.

Knudsen said, “If European politicians keep pushing pharma down and making it less and less attractive, then of course, as any other industry, we believe that that would be a loss for the European Union.”

title: Trump’s UK trade deal ignites market rally, rattles Goldman, and sets off global dominoes

On March 31, 2025, Goldman Sachs raised the probability of a U.S. recession within 12 months to 35% from 20%. They slashed their 2025 GDP growth forecast to 1% and increased inflation estimates. By April 7, 2025, Goldman further increased the recession probability to 45% from 35%. They cut their 2025 GDP growth forecast to 1.3% and projected three Federal Reserve rate cuts starting in June. On that very same day – April 9th. they changed their minds…. shortly after President Trump announced a 90-day pause on most tariffs (except for China, which faced 125% tariffs), Goldman Sachs rescinded their recession forecast. They reverted to a non-recession baseline BUT are still giving it a 45% chance of happening and a GDP growth forecast of 0.5% for 2025. title: Get the Facts: How President Trump's tariffs with Canada have evolved
content: This week marked an important milestone in the state of trade between the United States and Canada. Since February, the United States and Canada have entered into a series of trade measures and ...
resumen:
This week marked an important milestone in the state of trade between the United States and Canada.

President Donald Trump met with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Tuesday.

Carney, a former central banker who assumed office after Prime Minister Justin Trudeau resigned as leader of the center-left Liberal Party, won the Canadian election last week and has vowed to take on Trump and his tariffs.

During Trump's first term in office, the United States entered into a trade agreement called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA, which was signed on July 1, 2020.

On Feb. 1, 2025, Trump signed an executive order implementing a 25% additional tariff on imports from Canada and a 10% additional tariff on energy and potash, which was put on pause for 30 days a couple of days after the announcement.

Since then, the United States and Canada have entered into a series of trade measures and countermeasures.

In March, Canada started to impose counter-tariffs against the United States.

On March 4, Canada added tariffs on $30 billion worth of American goods in response to the 25% tariffs on Canadian exports and 10% tariffs on energy product exports.

When Trump imposed 25% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum products, Canada imposed countermeasures on March 12.

In April, when Trump's 25% tariff on Canadian automobiles took effect, Canada imposed 25% tariffs on vehicles from the United States that did not comply with USMCA.

Since the reciprocal tariffs were announced on April 2, Trump has reduced the tariffs to 10% across the board, implemented a 90-day pause, and raised tariffs on Chinese goods to 145%.

Canada was the top destination for U.S. exports and the third-largest source of U.S. imports in 2024.

Around $412.7 billion worth of goods were imported from Canada in 2024.

The meeting at the Oval Office between Carney and Trump on Tuesday bore no solutions to tariffs.

resumen: Solana Beach City Council members reviewed the draft budgets for the 2026 and 2027 fiscal years during their May 7 meeting, with some concern for how the Trump administration’s tariffs and general economic uncertainty might factor in. The city typically approves two-year budgets. The council will vote on whether to approve the budget for the next two fiscal years on June 18. Solana Beach City Manager Alyssa Muto said the budget for both fiscal years “does take into account a lot of uncertainties that exist right now in our world and in our country and in our state.” Solana Beach Mayor Lesa Heebner said she was concerned about sales tax revenue following the tariffs imposed by the Trump administration. In estimating negligible sales tax increases over the next two years, a city staff report said: “While the city remains optimistic that consumer spending activity is on the rise in the city and there will be businesses opening and more city growth on the horizon, staff maintains a conservative budget approach for FY 2026. Staff will analyze sales tax receipts at midyear and adjust these estimates if the results are more positive than anticipated.” Overall, proposed total general fund revenues in the draft budget are approximately $26.52 million and $27.59 million in the 2026 and 2027 fiscal years, respectively, and expenditures of $26.3 million and $27.3 million, based on the latest updates from city staff. The city is projecting a little more than $5 million in revenue from Measure S, a 1% sales tax approved by Solana Beach voters in 2022, in each of the next two fiscal years. The ending fund balance after the 2027 fiscal year is a projected $7.8 million. Councilmember David Zito said the budget should also reflect the future projects that the fund is trying to cover. Projects eligible for Measure S funding include maintaining local streets, storm drains and other infrastructure, maintaining parks, beaches, neighborhoods, and other public areas.

title: America's small businesses preparing for recession with Trump tariffs: CNBC|SurveyMonkey survey
content: Tariffs are not just impacting consumers and big corporations, but small businesses too, and that’s leading a majority on Main Street to brace for a recession.
resumen:
According to the latest quarterly CNBC|SurveyMonkey Small Business Survey, just 30% of small business owners said they would rate the current state of the economy as excellent or good. 70% said it's fair or poor. In the first quarter's poll, 39% rated the state of the economy as excellent or good.

70% of small business owners believe the country is headed towards a recession. Nearly all Democrat respondents forecast a recession while nearly half of Republicans did (47%) as well.

51% of respondents said they disapprove of the way Donald Trump is handling his job as president. This compares to 39% during his last quarter as president in 2020.

Small business confidence tracked by the survey is now lower than at any point during Trump's first term, other than during the worst quarter of the Covid crisis and the last quarter of his presidency.

The CNBC/SurveyMonkey poll was conducted between April 21-25, 2025, among a national sample of 2,257 self-identified small business owners.

51% of respondents said that they expect changes in trade policy to have a negative effect on their business over the next 12 months, compared to 27% that said it will have no effect and 21% that said it will have a positive effect.

Overall, 66% of small business owners either have been or expect to be impacted by tariffs.

Tariffs increased to 17%, up from 10% last quarter, while inflation (24%) and consumer demand (18%) remain the top risks listed by small business owners.

U.S. Chamber of Commerce CEO Suzanne Clark said the business lobbying group has been "inundated by small business requests for information, for relief" from the potential tariffs.

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has appealed to the Trump White House to automatically lift tariffs on all small business importers.

In a letter sent on April 30 to Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, Clark wrote, "We are deeply concerned that even if it only takes weeks or months to reach agreements, many small businesses will suffer irreparable harm."

The White House has not acted on those requests.

60% of respondents said they are either very or somewhat stressed about their businesses' finances these days, while 63% said they are very stressed or somewhat stressed about their own finances.

Tariffs ranked second as a contributor of stress.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell warned that the proposed tariffs could lead to a slowdown in economic growth and potentially a rise in long-term inflation.

President Trump said in a Truth Social post that he might be willing to lower tariffs on China to 80%.

On Friday, May 9, 2025, at the Port of Long Beach’s downtown headquarters, Rep. Robert Garcia (CA-42) and Rep. Nanette Barragán (CA-44) hosted a media conference to discuss the impact of the Trump administration’s tariffs.

Attendees included:
*   Port of Long Beach COO Noel Hacegaba
*   Long Beach Mayor Rex Richardson
*   Maria John, director of international logistics for ESI Enterprises

The conference focused on the negative impacts of the tariffs, with speakers stating they threaten the nation’s economy with rising prices and falling wages.

Rep. Robert Garcia stated that the tariffs are causing major damage and chaos to the economy, impacting the entire country.

President Donald Trump suggested bringing the 145% tariffs with China down to 80%.

Dockworkers and truck drivers are seeing work shifts and paychecks dwindle, and consumers across the country face high prices.

Noel Hacegaba noted that blank sailings are rising at the Port of Long Beach and spot shortages of goods will soon be evident by consumers in stores.

Maria John stated that importers are struggling with the back-and-forth information that has the industry trying to deal with a “domino effect.”

Rep. Barragán said Congress tried to overthrow national emergency legislation that enacted the tariffs but Republicans outnumbered Democrats and the effort failed.

Rep. Garcia added that the port communities of Long Beach and Los Angeles will take the hardest hits.

Rep. Barragán mentioned talking with the owner of the Sirens Java and Tea coffee house in downtown San Pedro, who was faced with either raising the price of her coffee or trying to absorb the higher prices in her small business.

title: Gabriela Calvo: "Rosario tiene todo para liderar el comercio exterior, solo falta que nos elijan más"
content: San Lorenzo es, sin dudas, un polo exportador clave para la provincia de Santa Fe. Y Rosario también juega un rol fundamental, especialmente en lo que respecta a cargas en contenedores. Después del ...
resumen:
Gabriela Calvo, secretaria del Centro de Despachantes de Aduana de Rosario, analiza el presente del comercio exterior en la región y en el país. Rosario cuenta con infraestructura y profesionales de primer nivel para operar en comercio exterior, y con una comunidad comprometida en sostener la actividad. La clave está en generar condiciones de competitividad reales: menos carga tributaria, un entorno regulatorio previsible, acceso al financiamiento y conectividad logística eficiente.

Gabriela Calvo fue presidenta del Centro de Despachantes de Aduana filial Rosario durante seis años y actualmente es secretaria. Esta filial abarca Rosario, San Lorenzo, Villa Constitución y Venado Tuerto. El Centro de Despachantes de Aduana tiene cinco filiales a nivel nacional. El trabajo del despachante de aduana está muy vinculado al territorio. Existe una gran articulación entre los despachantes de distintos lugares.

Rosario tiene puerto, aeropuerto, depósitos fiscales y corredor bioceánico, lo que le da un enorme potencial para seguir creciendo como región. Faltan pasos fundamentales para la reactivación plena, como el levantamiento total del cepo, la baja de retenciones a las exportaciones y la baja de impuestos o de presión fiscal. Las exportaciones siguen retraídas en comparación con las importaciones.

El sector exportador tiene potencial, pero necesita que todos los eslabones de la cadena estén conectados y empujen en la misma dirección. San Lorenzo es un polo exportador clave para la provincia de Santa Fe, y Rosario juega un rol fundamental en cargas en contenedores. El transporte terrestre también representa un volumen enorme.

Durante los 90 días de cierre de la pista del aeropuerto de Rosario, se recurrirá al envío de carga en camión a Ezeiza. La obra de reparación de la pista es estratégica porque permitirá recibir aviones más grandes.

Se necesita competir en igualdad de condiciones con Buenos Aires. Los forwarders de Buenos Aires tienden a centralizar las operaciones allá. Es fundamental que el cliente confíe en el profesional local.

El marco normativo cambia seguido, y estar informado es parte esencial del oficio del despachante de aduana. Se debe ofrecer igualdad de oportunidades al productor, al industrial y al exportador. No se puede abrir el comercio sin acompañar a los que producen y exportan.

Hoy se está importando mucho más de lo que se exporta. El levantamiento de la SEDI facilitó las cosas para muchos operadores.

title: El banco con presencia global anunció que su plataforma TradePay se ampliará para cubrir directamente el costo de los pagos de aranceles
content: El banco con presencia global anunció que su plataforma TradePay se ampliará para cubrir directamente el costo de los pagos de aranceles ...
resumen: HSBC Holdings Plc está ofreciendo un nuevo producto crediticio a las empresas estadounidenses que deben cubrir el costo de los aranceles impuestos por el presidente Donald Trump, que han afectado las cadenas de suministro internacionales. El banco con sede en Londres anunció el miércoles que su plataforma TradePay se ampliará para cubrir directamente el costo de los pagos de aranceles, lo que permitirá a los importadores obtener préstamos para hacer frente al aumento de los gastos derivados del envío de productos a Estados Unidos. Vivek Ramachandran, director de soluciones comerciales globales de HSBC, señaló: “Al liquidar los derechos de importación de forma directa y sin complicaciones a través de HSBC TradePay, nuestros clientes estadounidenses tienen más visibilidad y control sobre su capital circulante”. Con los nuevos préstamos, los pagos de importación de los clientes se abonarán automáticamente mediante créditos acordados de antemano con los bróker o mediante deducción directa utilizando créditos de la cámara de compensación automatizada, lo que significa que las empresas podrán gestionar mejor su flujo de caja y liquidar los derechos de manera más eficiente. HSBC es el banco comercial más grande del mundo y el mayor banco internacional en China, lo que le otorga un papel crucial en el comercio internacional, en particular entre las dos mayores economías. Estados Unidos ha impuesto aranceles de hasta el 145% a los productos chinos, mientras que China ha respondido con tasas de represalia del 125%. Se prevé que ambas naciones celebren conversaciones esta semana para calmar las tensiones. Mark Tucker, presidente de HSBC, señaló que el comercio mundial se enfrenta a un “periodo de cambios profundos y trascendentales”. “El impacto general del cambio de enfoque sobre las relaciones comerciales globales ha sido un aumento de la incertidumbre económica, con graves riesgos potenciales para el crecimiento global”, sostuvo Tucker.

title: China sienta a su mesa a la Celac para blindar su avance en Latinoamérica frente a EE. UU.
content: China sentará a su mesa el próximo 13 de mayo a los países latinoamericanos y caribeños en una reunión de cancilleres de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac) con la que el giga ...
resumen: China celebrará una reunión de cancilleres de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac) el 13 de mayo. El objetivo es tomar el pulso a su relación con la región y cimentar relaciones comerciales en expansión, amenazadas por Estados Unidos. Latinoamérica se ha convertido en un terreno de competencia entre Washington y Pekín. La asistencia de los presidentes de Brasil, Colombia, Uruguay, Chile y Honduras es una muestra de la importancia de China en la región, según Ángel Gallego, experto en China de la consultora Kreab. Los temas principales de la reunión serán “Interconexión eléctrica y energías renovables” e “Integración comercial”, alineados con los objetivos de China en América Latina: promover la iniciativa de las Nuevas Rutas de la Seda (BRI) y asegurar el acceso a recursos naturales como litio, tierras raras, petróleo y cobre. La iniciativa BRI busca generar una red comercial internacional y extender la influencia china. Estados Unidos logró que Panamá abandonara las Nuevas Rutas y se espera que Colombia se sume. China busca posicionarse como un socio para la industrialización en sectores de mayor valor añadido, cuidando las externalidades sociales y medioambientales. China se promueve como un socio fiable y estable, en contraste con Estados Unidos, no solo en el ámbito comercial, sino también en tecnologías y 5G. China busca aislar diplomáticamente a Taiwán, que reclama su soberanía desde 1949. Desde 2016, China ha arrebatado a Taiwán cinco aliados latinoamericanos: Panamá (2017), República Dominicana y El Salvador (2018), Nicaragua (2021) y Honduras (2023). De los doce Estados con los que Taiwán aún mantiene relaciones diplomáticas, siete (Paraguay, Guatemala, Belice, Haití, San Vicente y las Granadinas, Santa Lucía y San Cristóbal y Nieves) se sitúan en América Latina y el Caribe.

title: A delicate balance as China comes to negotiating table
content: Since US president Donald Trump imposed steep tariffs on China last month, Beijing has responded in kind. On state and social media, it posted images of Mao Zedong, lambasted "imperialists", and sent ...
resumen: Since US president Donald Trump imposed steep tariffs on China last month, Beijing has responded in kind. Chinese officials have grown increasingly alarmed about tariffs' impact on the economy and the risk of isolation as China's trading partners have started negotiating deals with Washington. These factors, along with outreach by the US and an easing of Trump's rhetoric, persuaded Beijing to send its economic tsar He Lifeng for meetings with US counterparts in Switzerland this weekend. Re-engagement was complicated by the fractious nature of US-China diplomacy. Beijing considered a letter the US side sent to Chinese ministries in late April about fentanyl "arrogant". Efforts to arrange talks were further impaired by disagreements over which officials should be involved. China's foreign ministry said in a statement to Reuters that it reiterated that "China's firm opposition to the US abuse of tariffs is consistent and clear, and there is no change". China's Vice Foreign Minister Hua Chunying said on Friday that China has full confidence in its ability to manage US trade issues, adding that the Trump administration's approach cannot be sustained. The trade war between the world's two largest economies, combined with Trump's decision last month to impose duties on dozens of other countries, has disrupted supply chains, unsettled financial markets and stoked fears of a sharp downturn in global growth. Chinese export restrictions, meanwhile, have squeezed the supply of critical minerals the US needs for weapons, electronics and consumer goods. Mr Trump's approval ratings are falling due to his handling of tariffs and the economy. The volatile run-up to the Geneva talks underscores the deep mistrust and divergent negotiating styles between the Trump team and China, which could make for protracted and fraught discussions. Scott Kennedy, an expert in Chinese business affairs at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) in Washington, said "Both sides I think are balancing trying to look tough with not wanting to be responsible for sinking the global economy". After Mr Trump's tariff salvo last month, China took a hard line in its public messaging. The tone began to shift on April 30, when a state media-affiliated blog said the US. had "proactively reached out to China through multiple channels, hoping to discuss tariffs". Contacts between Chinese agencies, Beijing's embassy in Washington, and the Trump administration had been increasing in frequency in recent weeks. Some in-person interactions took place at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in late April, including with US treasury secretary Scott Bessent, which paved the way for the Swiss meeting, said Kennedy. After Mr Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, Chinese commerce minister Wang Wentao quietly reached out to his US counterpart, Howard Lutnick, but was rebuffed as not senior enough, according to one official familiar with the exchanges. Mr Trump has been pushing for direct talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping. China has rejected that idea as not in keeping with its traditional approach of working out the details first before the leaders sign any deal. Another significant factor for China was Mr Trump's public berating of Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy in February, said one of the sources, adding that any unscripted hostile interaction between the US and Chinese leaders would represent an unacceptable loss of face for Mr Xi. As messaging on both sides grew more conciliatory, China decided to put forward its vice premier and Xi confidant He Lifeng, whose direct predecessor struck the "Phase One" trade deal with the US in 2019. The move satisfied Washington's demands for substantive talks with a senior official with direct access to Mr Xi, but avoided exposing the Chinese leader to potential embarrassment, said one of the sources. The Swiss foreign ministry said that "during its recent contacts in Washington and Beijing, Switzerland expressed to the US and Chinese authorities its willingness to organize a meeting between the two parties in Geneva." Among the main drivers of Beijing's climb-down were internal signals that Chinese companies were struggling to avoid bankruptcies and to replace the US market, three people familiar with the Chinese government's thinking said. US diplomats in China have also been closely monitoring factory closures, strikes, and job losses in the industrial heartland in southern China. Many analysts have downgraded their 2025 economic growth forecasts for China, and investment bank Nomura has warned the trade war could cost it up to 16 million jobs. China's central bank this week announced fresh monetary stimulus. One of the officials said Chinese companies were struggling to replace the US market because developing nations cannot buy as many items, and that for many firms this was an existential threat that needed to be resolved in days or weeks. Beijing was worried it was left without a place at the negotiating table while its major trading partners, such as Vietnam, India and Japan, began talks with Washington, said two officials familiar with Beijing's thinking. China's commerce ministry said in a statement this week that "appeasement cannot bring peace, compromise cannot be respected, and adhering to principled positions and upholding fairness and justice is the right way to safeguard one's own interests." As part of the push to counter the US, China is sending its Premier Li Qiang to Malaysia in late May for a summit with a newly established group of Southeast Asian and Arab nations, two sources told Reuters. In Geneva, Beijing appears to have modest expectations. Internally, China has downgraded the talks from a higher level to merely a meeting, reflecting its view that the discussions will be mostly about finding out Washington's demands and red lines after weeks of contradictory messages by Mr Trump and other senior US officials, according to a person familiar with the matter. One official said China could draw on its extensive toolbox and follow Asian neighbors in offering to buy more American liquefied natural gas. On the table may also be purchases of agricultural goods, similar to the 2019 "Phase One" deal during Trump's first term. At the time, Beijing said it would increase purchases of US agricultural products by $32bn (€28bn) over two years. Even before triggering the broader trade war, Trump imposed a 20% tariff on Chinese goods, saying Beijing wasn't doing enough to counter the flow of chemicals used to produce the deadly drug fentanyl. One of the moves that complicated the rapprochement, according to two officials, was a letter sent by the US to China in late April that outlined the steps Trump wanted Beijing to take on fentanyl. The document, reviewed by Reuters, caused friction with Beijing because it referenced a congressional report that asserted China, through value-added tax rebates for exporters, directly subsidizes production of fentanyl precursors for sale abroad. The letter, sent to the ministries of foreign affairs, commerce, and public security, called on Beijing to publicize the crackdown on fentanyl precursors on the front page of the Communist Party mouthpiece People's Daily; send a similar message through "internal party channels" to party members; tighten regulation of some specified chemicals; and deepen law-enforcement cooperation. Two officials familiar with China's reaction said it found especially the first two points "arrogant" because Beijing saw it as the US dictating what China should do within its ruling apparatus. One said fentanyl would feature in the Geneva talks and that the US government's opening position would be to present the four points to China. title: There are more than 12,000 kilometers between China and Mexico
content: Lula, Boric, and Petro, ideologically aligned with Sheinbaum, are moving closer to China, but Mexico has reasons to keep its distance.
resumen:
*   There are more than 12,000 kilometers between China and Mexico.
*   Lula, Boric, and Petro, ideologically aligned with Sheinbaum, are moving closer to China, but Mexico has reasons to keep its distance.
*   The importance of China’s investment, technology, and political, cultural, and educational influence in Latin America is increasingly evident.
*   China has expanded its presence in the region through trade agreements, infrastructure projects, and soft power strategies such as the Confucius Institute.
*   The five Latin American countries that receive the most Chinese investment are Brazil, Chile, Peru, Mexico, and Ecuador.
*   The presidents of Brazil, Colombia, and Chile—Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Gustavo Petro, and Gabriel Boric, respectively—are leading delegations from the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) on a visit to China to strengthen trade ties and explore alternatives.
*   These visits coincide with the fourth meeting of foreign ministers of the China-CELAC Forum.
*   In February, Mexico faced a 25% tariff on all Mexican imports from the United States.
*   President Claudia Sheinbaum has voiced concern over the huge trade imbalance with China and has made it clear that the United States remains Mexico’s top trading priority.
*   From 2006 to 2024, direct investment from China reached $2.549 billion.
*   China has developed infrastructure in Mexico, particularly in industrial parks in areas like Nuevo León, Baja California, the State of Mexico, Coahuila, and Chihuahua.
*   Most of these investments occurred between 2018 and 2024.
*   The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative has already expressed concern about the level of Chinese investment in Mexico’s automotive sector.
*   Mexico has remained relatively steady under the protective framework of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).
*   In 2024 alone, Mexico imported more than $129 billion in goods from China but exported only $9.932 billion.
*   China’s growing presence follows a clear, phased strategy: extractivist activity, then large-scale infrastructure projects, and more recently, leadership in technology and digital commerce.
*   China supports authoritarian governments like those in Venezuela and Nicaragua.
*   According to Freedom in the World (2025), China is classified as “not free.”
*   In China, there is no independent civil society, no freedom of expression, association, assembly, or religion, and human rights defenders and critics of the regime are persecuted.
*   Mexico’s relationship with the U.S. didn’t start with Trump.
*   Migration remains a humanitarian crisis.
*   Mexico has positioned itself as the United States’ leading trading partner, developed an attractive investment profile, and become more competitive with China.
*   Jorge Guajardo, former Mexican ambassador to China, has noted that the U.S. shutting its doors to its rival benefits Mexico, as China directly competes with it commercially.

title: Britain’s Roller-Coaster Ride to a Trade Deal With Trump
content: At times during weeks of thorny negotiations, the efforts of Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government seemed destined to fail.
resumen: For Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, the road to a first-in-the-world trade deal with the United States began on a late winter afternoon when he arrived in the Oval Office, bearing a letter for President Trump from King Charles III, inviting Mr. Trump for a rare second state visit to Britain. It ended on Thursday afternoon when Mr. Starmer was patched into the Oval Office for a theatrical, televised phone call with Mr. Trump, in which the president announced a deal that will roll back tariffs on some British exports, including autos and steel, while leaving other tariffs in place. The deal, Mr. Trump declared, will be “so good for both countries.” Mr. Starmer said the agreement testified to the value of not being provoked by Mr. Trump’s sometimes aggressive tactics. The nine weeks between Mr. Starmer’s visit in February and his phone call Thursday with Mr. Trump were a roller-coaster ride for the prime minister and his negotiators. Kim Darroch said, critics could argue that Mr. Trump had not lifted all the tariffs and might yet reverse course on elements of the agreement. On April 2, Britain was swept into the same basic 10 percent tariff that the United States imposed on dozens of countries. Its steel and auto industry had already been slapped with tariffs. Mr. Starmer has tried to act as a bridge between Mr. Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine. Mr. Starmer said in an interview with The New York Times in March, “I’ve met him a number of times now. I’ve spoken to him on numerous cases on the phone. I think we have a really good relationship.” Among the issues the two leaders discussed was Mr. Trump’s golf club in Scotland, Trump Turnberry. In late March, Mr. Starmer told the president that the police had arrested three people on suspicion of vandalizing the resort with pro-Palestinian messages. Mr. Trump referred to them as “terrorists.” British officials pushed back against Mr. Trump’s claim that Mr. Starmer was “very happy” that Britain had only been hit with a 10 percent tariff, not 20 percent, as had the European Union. Part of the challenge for Britain, a senior official said, was toggling between Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, and Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary. British officials also expressed anxiety that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent might prioritize securing an agreement with a larger Asian economy like Japan. Britain was helped in the negotiation by having Peter Mandelson as its new ambassador to Washington. During Mr. Trump’s phone call with Mr. Starmer on Thursday, Mr. Mandelson stood behind the president in the Oval Office. The breakthrough came on Wednesday, when British negotiators in Washington called Jonathan Reynolds, the country’s secretary for business and trade, to ask whether the government would greenlight the latest draft of the deal, which it did. Mr. Trump still placed one last call to Mr. Starmer, seeking concessions, on Wednesday night in London. Mr. Starmer decided to travel to a Jaguar Land Rover factory, outside Birmingham, to showcase how the deal would cut tariffs on cars from about 25 percent to 10 percent.

title: Baffled by the Trump Tariffs, C.E.O.s Lean on the Word ‘Uncertainty’
content: With little ability to see how far the Trump administration is taking its disruptive policies, corporations and investors face higher risks, our columnist says.
resumen:
Ford and General Motors executives say they can’t estimate what lies ahead. Both companies have suspended earnings guidance. A broad range of companies, including Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines, Skechers, UPS and Cummins, say they can’t talk confidently about the future.

Executives used “uncertainty” in 87 percent of earnings calls this season, compared with 38 percent in the previous three months. Executives used “tariffs” in 93 percent of earnings calls. “Recession” came up in 30 percent of these discussions, versus 3 percent in the previous quarter.

Sherry House, Ford’s chief financial officer, said they are suspending guidance for full year 2025. She enumerated some of the things that Ford doesn’t know: industrywide supply chain disruption impacting production; future or increased tariffs in the U.S.; changes in the implementation of tariffs, including tariff offsets; retaliatory tariffs and other restrictions by other governments and the potential related market impacts; and finally, policy uncertainties associated with tax and emissions policy.

President Trump wants the U.S. military to enter Mexico to fight the drug cartels. He urged Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s president, to approve a U.S. military incursion. She responded: “I told him, ‘No, President Trump, our territory is inviolable, our sovereignty is inviolable, our sovereignty is not for sale.” She added, “We will never accept the presence of the army of the United States on our territory.”

In a White House meeting with Mark Carney, Canada’s new prime minister, Mr. Trump insisted that one day Canada would become the 51st state. Prime Minister Carney quickly responded: “It’s not for sale it won’t be for sale, ever.” Mr. Trump said, “Never say never.”

Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said on a May 1 earnings call that tariffs in the three months starting in June are most likely to add $900 million to Apple’s costs. He said that estimate assumes “the current global tariff rates, policies and applications do not change for the balance of the quarter, and no new tariffs are added.” Mr. Cook warned that “this estimate should not be used to make projections for future quarters.”

Mr. Cook said, “We do expect the majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. will have India as their country of origin and Vietnam to be the country of origin for almost all iPad, Mac, Apple Watch and AirPods products. China would continue to be the country of origin for the vast majority of total product sales outside the U.S.”

U.S. tariffs on many Chinese products now stand at 145 percent. Apple, is, for now, benefiting from a temporary exemption from tariffs on smartphones from China.

The first official U.S.-Chinese meeting since the start of the trade conflict is scheduled for this weekend in Geneva.

The Federal Reserve said in a statement this past week, “Uncertainty about the economic outlook has increased further.” Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said in a news conference, “There’s so much uncertainty about the scale, scope, timing and persistence of the tariffs.” The Fed will hold interest rates steady.

Stock analysts are projecting a deceleration in profit growth for U.S. corporations, but they have not, for the most part, included the possibility of a recession. They are penciling in a likely reduction in the rate of profit growth this year — but expect profits to keep growing — with a re-acceleration in 2026.

title: UK-US trade deal a 'huge relief', minister says, as businesses call for more clarity
content: Darren Jones says the government "has protected jobs because of this trade deal", as shadow trade secretary Andrew Griffith calls it "disappointing".
resumen:
The US and UK have agreed on a trade deal to reduce import taxes on some British cars and metals.

The deal includes:
*   Reducing tariffs on cars exported to the US from 27.5% to 10% for a quota of 100,000 UK cars.
*   Scrapping the 25% tariffs on UK steel and aluminum imported by the US.
*   "Reciprocal market access" on beef, with a quota for UK farmers to export 13,000 metric tonnes of beef to the US, and the US granted the same.
*   Creating a secure supply chain for pharmaceutical products, with final details to be written up in the coming weeks.
*   Preferential access for the US to high-quality UK aerospace components.
*   The reciprocal tariff rate of 10% on the UK, which was announced in March, remains in place.

Chancellor Rachel Reeves described the deal as a "good deal." Treasury Minister Darren Jones said that 150,000 jobs had been "protected."

Shadow trade secretary Andrew Griffith said that a more "comprehensive" agreement is needed to grow the UK economy.

British Airways' parent company announced it had bought 32 new Boeing planes from the US.

Liam Bates, from stainless steel manufacturer Marcegaglia, said the announcement was "very significant," but adds that it would "be good to get more clarity."

Farmers have also had a mixed reaction to the deal.

The US-UK trade deal has been described as "historic" by both Trump and Starmer.

Economists have weighed in on the situation saying that, though the lack of concessions on the UK side could be viewed as a success, the deal is unlikely to boost Britain's economy much.

The UK's digital services tax was not revised as part of the deal.

The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, welcomed the tariff pact struck between the US and the UK.

The director general of UK Steel says the industry is still waiting to learn the exact details of yesterday's UK-US trade agreement.

The Governor of the Bank of England has said the UK now needs to "rebuild" Britain's trade relationship with the European Union.

Sheffield steel manufacturer Liam Bates, president of Marcegaglia says the news is "very significant."

Car manufacturer Jaguar Land Rover says the deal "secures greater certainty for our sector" after import charges were lowered from 25% to 10% on the first 100,000 exports.

Ian McCubbine, a beef farmer in Surrey, tells BBC Radio 4's Today programme that "we have to be careful that we are stringent about food standards."

title: USD/MXN Forecast: Tariff Reprieve May Shield Mexican Peso, Say Rabobank
content: Rabobank stops short of providing a precise USD/MXN target, but the message is clear: volatility will persist, yet Mexico’s participation in a “Fortress America” strategy could ultimately anchor the ...
resumen: El peso mexicano ha sufrido una fuerte venta este año, con el USD/MXN subiendo un 20% desde los mínimos de abril, impulsado por las conmociones políticas y comerciales a ambos lados de la frontera. Molly Schwartz de Rabobank argumenta que, a pesar de la agitación, la evolución del panorama arancelario y la realineación de México con los objetivos comerciales de Estados Unidos pueden ayudar a estabilizar el peso con el tiempo. La debilidad del MXN fue impulsada por varios eventos geopolíticos importantes, incluyendo la victoria electoral de Morena, el deshacerse de las operaciones de carry trade de MXN/JPY tras la subida de tipos del Banco de Japón y, más recientemente, el regreso de Donald Trump a la Casa Blanca, reavivando los temores de aranceles punitivos sobre las exportaciones mexicanas. Schwartz destaca que la postura de Trump ha evolucionado, con exenciones introducidas en el marco del T-MEC y tasas reducidas para las principales exportaciones mexicanas. Los aranceles que amenazan a México han evolucionado, pasando de aranceles generales del 25% a tasas libres de aranceles para los bienes que cumplen con el T-MEC y una tasa reducida del 10% para la energía y la potasa mexicanas. El peso también está respaldado por señales de alineación con los objetivos estratégicos de Estados Unidos. La presidenta Sheinbaum ha respaldado públicamente la relocalización de las cadenas de suministro y los lazos comerciales fuera de China y hacia Norteamérica, una postura que podría valer a México nuevas concesiones de Washington. Sheinbaum afirma explícitamente que México necesita relocalizarse fuera de China y hacia la producción nacional y el comercio con Canadá y Estados Unidos. Los riesgos a corto plazo del USD/MXN siguen siendo de dos caras. La indulgencia arancelaria podría mejorar la posición comercial de México y elevar el peso, pero la incertidumbre persistente sobre la estrategia económica más amplia de Trump y las órdenes IEEPA vinculadas a la frontera pueden seguir pesando en el sentimiento. Hay presiones tanto al alza como a la baja sobre México y el peso: al alza por las posibles reducciones arancelarias, a la baja por las restricciones restantes. Rabobank no proporciona un objetivo preciso para el USD/MXN, pero el mensaje es claro: la volatilidad persistirá, pero la participación de México en una estrategia de "Fortaleza América" podría, en última instancia, anclar el peso, evitando otra subida sostenida del USD/MXN.

content: It’s no surprise that Donald Trump’s first trade “deal” after his disastrous tariffs is more-so a framework than a done deal, but a handshake with British Prime Minister ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump, with Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, Vice President JD Vance, and Britian's ambassador to the United States Peter Mandelson, made remarks on a trade deal between U.S. and U.K. in the Oval Office of the White House, Thursday, May 8, 2025, in Washington.
Donald Trump’s first trade “deal” after his disastrous tariffs is more-so a framework than a done deal, but a handshake with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer is better than a trade war.
The U.S. has some other 190 countries to work out deals with, including all of our largest trading partners.
Trump’s tariff scheme seems to morph every day.
The damage is already being done, and will soon be felt more acutely by American consumers.
Even if, by some miracle, the U.S. strikes a real deal tomorrow with China that brings our tariff posture back to reasonable levels, we’ve already had weeks of container ships coming over half empty from the largest producer of clothes and household goods, among other things.
The idea that we may start seeing empty store shelves pretty soon is neither a hypothetical nor an extrapolation; it is a near certainty at this point, no matter what the administration does.
Tariffs would threaten the stability of the global economy, reduce the flow of crucial goods into the United States and result in global antagonism that would make deals much harder to consummate.
Trump has hand-waved away criticism under the idea that other countries need us while we do not need them.
We are absolutely reliant on imports of various varieties that we cannot easily replicate domestically, and plenty of domestic U.S. businesses are suffering while unable to easily export products to countries that have instituted reciprocal tariffs.
The underlying notion that it is necessary for us to have net zero trade balance with every other country in the world and that deficits are inherently bad is preposterous and would have gotten Trump laughed out of an economics class, yet is now the official policy of the United States.

resumen: A US-UK trade deal was announced on Thursday evening, May 8, 2025. Tariffs of 27.5 percent on UK cars will be reduced to 10 percent for a quota of 100,000 cars. Tariffs on UK steel and aluminium will be removed. There will also be exemptions for UK aerospace components, in return for British Airways ordering 30 Boeing 787 Dreamliner jets. All other exports to the US will incur a blanket 10 percent tariff. A reciprocal agreement on beef allows both countries to export 13,000 metric tonnes at a reduced tariff rate of 4-10 percent for UK exporters and tariff-free for US exporters. The US is also granted a tariff exemption on the first 1.4 billion litres of ethanol exported to the UK. There have been vague suggestions of preferential treatment when it comes to tariffs on pharmaceuticals. Average UK tariffs on US products have fallen from 5.1 percent to 1.8 percent since Trump became president, while average US tariffs on UK goods have increased from 3.4 percent to 10 percent. The deal is a signal from Sir Keir Starmer’s Labour government that it is prioritising relations with America over those with Europe. The EU published a 200-page catalogue of more than 4,800 goods imported from the US which could be hit with tariffs totalling close to €100 billion. A UK-EU summit is scheduled in London on May 19. The BBC’s economics editor, Faisal Islam, explains the British government’s intentions. Bank of England Chief Andrew Bailey was quick to argue for the UK to “start to rebuild that relationship” with the EU. Der Spiegel warns of the US-UK deal, “According to the White House, the creation of a ‘trading community’ for steel and aluminum is planned. This could mean that in future, the UK could impose a 25 percent tariff on imports from third countries such as Germany.” Politico reports that French President Emmanuel “Macron is playing hardball as Starmer strives for EU reset”, with France aiming “to limit British access to a €150 billion European rearmament defense fund that is being negotiated.”

title: Americans still dream about factory jobs. Can they be brought back?
content: Trump's administration said they want tariffs to boost US manufacturing, and most Americans want more factory jobs here. But what makes us nostalgic for factory work?
resumen:
President Trump's administration wants tariffs to boost US manufacturing, and most Americans want more factory jobs here.

President Trump said, "Jobs in factories will come roaring back into our country," when he announced reciprocal tariffs last month. "We will supercharge our domestic industrial base."

The American manufacturing sector has lost over a third of its workers since its peak of 19.6 million workers in 1979, now employing 12.7 million.

A poll from the Cato Institute and YouGov shows that 80% of Americans say the country would be better off if more Americans worked in manufacturing.

Jeffrey Gonzalez, associate professor of English at Montclair State University, wrote a paper about "smokestack nostalgia".

Salaries for manufacturing jobs are now in the bottom half of all jobs.

A paper by researchers at the Federal Reserve shows that the decline in unionization rates is, by and large, responsible for the drop in wages for factory work compared to other jobs.

Dylan Matthews, Vox senior correspondent, adds that some of the cultural nostalgia for factory work might stem from guilt some people might have about their "email jobs".

Republican politicians including Vice President J.D. Vance have also made national security arguments for opening more factories in the U.S. that could produce weapons.

Bernie Sanders has recently called for rebuilding American manufacturing.

Revitalizing American manufacturing was also a priority of former Presidents Biden and Obama.

There are 400,000 open positions in manufacturing as of February, according to the National Association of Manufacturers.

One new paper by Robert Z. Lawrence, Harvard's Albert L. Williams Professor of International Trade and Investment, suggests that productivity growth beats out foreign competition for the most blame for factory job losses.

As of 2023, there are 3.2 million foreign-born workers in manufacturing, about 25% of all manufacturing workers.

The last time President Trump issued import tariffs, they did not increase or decrease employment in protected sectors, according to one analysis in the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: Trump, Starmer hail limited US-UK trade deal
content: US President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Thursday announced a limited bilateral trade agreement that leaves in place Trump's 10% tariffs on British exports, modestly ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced a limited bilateral trade agreement.

The agreement leaves in place Trump's 10% tariffs on British exports, expands agricultural access for both countries, and lowers US duties on British car exports.

The deal is the first of dozens of tariff-lowering deals that Trump expects to land in coming weeks.

Trump hailed the deal in the Oval Office with Starmer on a speaker phone.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and top trade negotiator Jamieson Greer head to Switzerland to launch negotiations with Chinese negotiators.

Trump imposed reciprocal duties of up to 50% on goods from 57 trading partners including the European Union, pausing them days later to allow time for negotiations until July 9.

He has also heaped new 25% tariffs on auto imports, ended all exemptions on steel and aluminum duties, and announced new tariff probes on pharmaceuticals, copper, lumber and semiconductors.

This week he added movies to the list.

Starmer said the announcement came nearly at the same hour 80 years ago when World War Two ended in Europe.

The two leaders heralded the plan as a "breakthrough deal" that lowers average British tariffs on US goods to 1.8% from 5.1% but keeps in place a 10% tariff on British goods.

A UK official said the deal did not include Washington's demand for restructuring of Britain's digital services tax, levied at 2% of UK revenue for online marketplaces.

Trump's first trade deal fuelled a rally on Wall Street, sending major US indexes briefly up over 1%.

The S&P 500 passenger airlines index closed up 5.4%, led by a 7.2% surge in Delta Air Lines as US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said British-made Rolls-Royce engines would enter the US duty-free.

Lutnick said Washington will roll out dozens of trade deals over the next month.

Trump's biggest challenge is resolving a virtual trade embargo between the US and China, with tariffs of 145% and 125%, respectively on each side.

Greer and Bessent will lead talks with Chinese officials in Switzerland, on Saturday and Sunday.

The British-American Business group expressed disappointment that the deal leaves in place Trump's 10% tariffs for many products, including cars.

The deal will provide potential new export opportunities for American producers worth $5 billion a year, Lutnick said, while the higher tariffs would generate $6 billion in annual US revenue.

It will reduce US tariffs on British auto imports to 10% from the current 27.5%.

The lower rate will apply to a quota of 100,000 British vehicles.

US tariffs on imports from the struggling UK steel industry will fall to zero from 25%.

Britain's 19% tariffs on US ethanol will fall to zero through a 1.4 billion-liter (370 million gallon) quota.

Both sides have agreed to new reciprocal market access on beef, with UK farmers given a first-ever tariff-free quota for 13,000 metric tonnes.

There will be no weakening of UK food standards on imports.

US beef bred with growth hormones still won't be allowed in.

US Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said the deal would "exponentially increase" US beef exports to Britain.

Details were scant on tariffs on UK pharmaceuticals imports, which could damage AstraZeneca and GSK, although a White House fact sheet said the deal would create a secure pharma supply chain.

The US agreed to give Britain preferential treatment in any further tariffs imposed under Section 232 national security investigations, which include ongoing probes of pharmaceutical and semiconductor imports.

GSK and AstraZeneca declined comment.

The UK official also welcomed Trump's assurance during the Oval Office event on finding ways to avoid his new push to tariff foreign-made movies.

Starmer's government has been seeking to build new trading relationships post-Brexit with the US, China and the EU.

The tariffs had added to the pressure on his government.

Jaguar Land Rover paused its shipments to the US for a month and the government was forced to seize control of British Steel to keep it operating.

Britain struck a free trade agreement with India this week.

content: Las tensiones comerciales a nivel global han creado una disrupción fuerte en los flujos de comercio y parecerían solo la antesala de cambios ...

Donald Trump sugirió rebajar al 80% los aranceles que impuso a China, en la víspera de negociaciones comerciales entre ambos países en Suiza.

title: Trump’s tariffs are driving up Ford car prices: These are the Mexico-made models that will cost more
content: Ford informed dealers that it is raising the price of three models produced in Mexico by as much as $2,000 effective 2 May due to Trump’s tariffs.
resumen:
Ford informó a los concesionarios que está aumentando el precio de tres modelos producidos en México hasta en $2,000 a partir del 2 de mayo debido a los aranceles de Trump.

Los aumentos de precios se aplicarán al Bronco Sport, la camioneta Maverick y el SUV eléctrico Mustang Mach-E construidos después del 2 de mayo de este año, que llegarán a los lotes de los concesionarios en algún momento de junio.

En un aviso a los concesionarios visto por Reuters, el fabricante de automóviles dijo que los precios aumentarán hasta $2,000.

Un portavoz de Ford dijo que los aumentos de precios fueron el resultado de las "acciones de precios de mitad de año habituales de la compañía combinadas con los aranceles que enfrentamos".

El fabricante de automóviles dijo que asumiría parte de la carga financiera de los aranceles de Trump sobre los automóviles ensamblados importados a los EE. UU. "No hemos trasladado el costo total de los aranceles a nuestros clientes", dijo el portavoz de Ford.

Ford espera menores ganancias en 2025.

El lunes de esta semana, Ford retiró su guía financiera para todo el año citando la incertidumbre económica creada por las políticas comerciales de la Casa Blanca. Sin embargo, la compañía espera que los aranceles causen una merma de $1.5 mil millones en sus ganancias ajustadas antes de intereses e impuestos.

Hablando en una llamada de ganancias, el CEO de Ford, Jim Farley, dijo a los analistas que "todavía es demasiado pronto para comprender completamente las respuestas de nuestros competidores a estos aranceles". Sin embargo, vio un beneficio potencial para la compañía que tiene una mayor proporción de los automóviles que vende en los EE. UU. ensamblados a nivel nacional. "Está claro... que en este nuevo entorno, los fabricantes de automóviles con la mayor presencia en los EE. UU. tendrán una gran ventaja", señaló.

title: Ni Nike ni Adidas: esta empresa de calzado promete no subir los precios por los aranceles
content: Mientras marcas como Nike y Adidas anuncian alzas por los aranceles, Keen garantiza que mantendrá sus precios y nos trasladará al consumidor los nuevos costos ...
resumen: Mientras marcas como Nike y Adidas anuncian alzas por los aranceles, Keen garantiza que mantendrá sus precios y no trasladará al consumidor los nuevos costos. La marca Keen no es tan famosa como Adidas o Nike, pero son de buena calidad y con excelente mercado en EE.UU. La empresa con sede en Portland asegura que no trasladará los costos adicionales a sus clientes este año. Keen ha decidido asumir el impacto económico sin afectar al consumidor. El director de operaciones, Hari Perumal, declaró a CBS MoneyWatch que Keen se ha estado preparando para esto durante más de una década y decidió diversificar su cadena de suministro mucho más allá de China. En una industria donde el 36% del calzado vendido en EE.UU. proviene de China, equivalente a casi $10 mil millones de dólares según TD Cowen, la decisión de Keen ha resultado clave. Keen fabrica productos en Kentucky, República Dominicana y Tailandia, además de colaborar con socios en India, Vietnam y Camboya. A pesar de los nuevos aranceles que se avecinan, de hasta 49% en el caso de Camboya, solo el 10% de la producción de Keen se ve directamente afectada por estas medidas. Perumal comentó que el arancel del 10% que están manejando es significativamente menor que el que enfrentan otras compañías sobre productos que salen de China. La empresa ha logrado distribuir los costos a lo largo de toda su red de producción, incluyendo a los fabricantes asociados y a los proveedores de materiales. Adidas ya advirtió que los consumidores estadounidenses enfrentarán aumentos por los costos derivados de los aranceles. Otras marcas han implementado cargos adicionales etiquetados como “sobretasas por arancel”. Jason Judd, director del Global Labor Institute de Cornell University, estima que el gasto anual por familia en ropa y calzado podría pasar de $1,700 a $2,800 dólares a corto plazo, y se mantendría en unos $425 dólares adicionales por año.

title: RD no puede fallar a su aliado USA y sacar provecho de China (OPINION)
content: Nos sentimos sorprendidos por la calculada superficialidad con que los medios de prensa de opinión audiovisuales norteamericanos definen la estrategia de gobierno del presidente Trump y los presagios ...
resumen:
El autor, periodista residente en Juan Dolio, San Pedro de Macorís, escribe sobre la estrategia de gobierno del presidente Trump y los presagios catastróficos que hacen de ella los medios de prensa de opinión audiovisuales norteamericanos.

El autor menciona a Andy Dauhjare, formado en la escuela de Milton Friedman en Harvard, quien ayuda a comprender lo que acontece. Dauhajre publicó en El Caribe el artículo “El Arancel, ¿Santo Grial de la Economía de EEUU?” que identifica los basamentos económicos de lo que entonces era promesa de gobierno.

Dauhajre cita a Stephen Miran y Peter Navarro, economistas que parecen tener el oído del presidente Trump, quienes entienden que EE. UU. puede aprovechar su poder “monopsónico” para imponer el “arancel óptimo”.

En 2023, según la Organización Mundial del Comercio (WTO), EE. UU. tuvo una participación de 15.8% en el total de las importaciones mundiales de bienes manufacturados, seguida por la Unión Europea con 11.4% (36.0%), China con 8.2%, Reino Unido con 3.3%, México con 2.9%, Canadá con 2.7%, Japón con 2.6%, Corea del Sur con 2.4% e India con 2.1%.

Miran fue seleccionado por Trump para ocupar la jefatura del Consejo de Asesores Económicos de su gobierno. Miran publicó un documento titulado “A User’s Guide to Restructuring the Global Trade System”.

Miran incluye una sección denominada “Tarifas y Compensación de Moneda” en la que sostiene que el establecimiento de tarifas no tiene necesariamente que impactar el nivel de precios de la economía de un país grande como EE. UU.

El autor concluye que Trump no es un improvisado, sino un ejecutor de un proyecto de conducción económica que tiene seguidores en los más altos estratos económicos de su país.

El autor considera que la República Dominicana debe sacar el mayor provecho posible de este escenario de lucha por la preservación de mercados e influencia.

El autor señala que el gobierno del presidente Abinader tiene claro que su principal aliado es Estados Unidos y que, si el país estableció relaciones con China, lo inteligente es diversificar el comercio y crear una alternativa a la dependencia de USA.

title: Putin y Xi rechazan aranceles comerciales «injustos», medidas proteccionistas y sanciones unilaterales de EE.UU
content: –Los presidentes ruso, Vladímir Putin, y chino, Xi Jinping, lanzaron este jueves un serio aviso a Estados Unidos con una declaración estratégica en la que condenaron tanto su política de contención, ...
resumen:
Los presidentes ruso, Vladímir Putin, y chino, Xi Jinping, lanzaron este jueves una declaración estratégica en la que condenaron la política de contención de Estados Unidos, la expansión de la OTAN en Europa y Asia, y las barreras comerciales impuestas por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump.

Durante su reunión en el Kremlin, Putin y Xi aseguraron que su alianza, que definieron como un «factor estabilizador» en tiempos de incertidumbre geopolítica, no está dirigida contra ningún país.

Putin y Xi aprobaron dos declaraciones políticas que reflejaron las tensiones entre el eje Moscú-Pekín y el que forman Washington y Bruselas.

Las partes «tienen la intención de ampliar la cooperación y reforzar la coordinación con el fin de contrarrestar con firmeza la política de Washington de ‘doble contención’ de Rusia y China», señala el documento, que criticó el sistema antimisiles Cúpula de Hierro y advirtió del riesgo de un conflicto nuclear.

Ambos dirigentes consideran la expansión de la OTAN en Asia-Pacífico «extremadamente negativo para la paz, la estabilidad y la prosperidad de la región».

Aseguraron que los planes de EE.UU. y el Reino Unido de crear una infraestructura militar en Australia (en alusión a la alianza tripartita AUKUS) únicamente «provocarán una carrera armamentista en la región».

Putin y Xi alertaron de que la expansión de algunas potencias nucleares que despliegan misiles de corto y medio alcance lejos de su territorio, en clara alusión a EEUU, amenazan los intereses fundamentales de otros países que también disponen de arsenal estratégico, como es el caso de Rusia y China.

Rusia y China denunciaron los aranceles comerciales «injustos», la competencia desleal, las medidas proteccionistas y las sanciones unilaterales.

«La introducción de aranceles injustificados por parte de determinados Estados hacia sus socios comerciales va contra los derechos e intereses de otros Estados y la Organización Mundial del Comercio, (…) lo que amenaza a la estabilidad mundial», señala.

En su opinión, dichas medidas «discriminatorias» influyen negativamente en la economía mundial y en la seguridad alimentaria y energética.

En cuanto a la congelación de activos, del que es ahora víctima Rusia, defienden el derecho a tomar medidas de respuesta en virtud del derecho internacional.

Rusia y China firmaron un acuerdo de fomento y protección de inversiones, que Putin estimó en 200.000 millones de dólares, lo que elevaría a un billón el dinero total invertido en proyectos conjuntos, según el Kremlin.

Putin también dio la bienvenida a los fabricantes de coches y microprocesadores chinos, y prometió que Gazprom satisfará las necesidades de gas chinas incluso por encima del tope marcado por los contratos bilaterales.

En el caso de Irán llamaron a solucionar el problema nuclear sobre la base del Tratado de No Proliferación, pero también del uso pacífico de la energía atómica.

La declaración defiende el concepto de seguridad indivisible -un país no puede garantizar su seguridad a costa de otro-, argumento esgrimido por Rusia para defender su campaña militar en Ucrania, que aspiraba a ingresar en la OTAN.

Rusia también alabó en el documento conjunto la postura objetiva e imparcial y el papel constructivo jugado por Pekín, al que el presidente ucraniano, Volodímir Zelenski, acusó recientemente de enviar tropas y equipos militares a Rusia.

Aprovechando la presencia en Moscú de los líderes de Brasil, Venezuela y Cuba, alabaron la voluntad de los países latinoamericanos hacia una cooperación mutuamente beneficiosa y se mostraron dispuestos a incrementar los contactos con las organizaciones regionales.

El presidente chino, Xi Jinping declaró que ante la contracorriente del unilateralismo y el acto de la política de poder y la intimidación en el mundo, China trabajará con Rusia para asumir la responsabilidad especial que les corresponde como grandes países y miembros permanentes del Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU.

Los dos líderes intercambiaron puntos de vista en profundidad sobre las relaciones China-Rusia y acerca de importantes asuntos internacionales y regionales, y llegaron a un consenso sobre la profundización inquebrantable de la coordinación estratégica y la promoción del desarrollo estable, sano y de alto nivel de las relaciones China-Rusia.

Los dos líderes también pidieron promover la perspectiva histórica correcta sobre la Segunda Guerra Mundial, mantener la autoridad y el estatus de las Naciones Unidas y salvaguardar la justicia y la equidad internacionales.

Xi dijo que la historia y la realidad han demostrado plenamente que seguir desarrollando y profundizando las relaciones China-Rusia es integral para impulsar la amistad entre los dos pueblos de generación en generación, y añadió que es una opción inevitable para que ambas partes alcancen el éxito mutuo y promuevan su propio desarrollo y revitalización.

También es el llamado de los tiempos para salvaguardar la equidad y la justicia internacionales y promover la reforma del sistema de gobernanza global, explicó Xi.

Putin dijo que las relaciones entre Rusia y China se basan en la igualdad y el respeto mutuos, no están dirigidas contra terceros y no se ven afectadas por incidentes temporales.

Promover inquebrantablemente el desarrollo de las relaciones entre Rusia y China y ampliar la cooperación mutuamente beneficiosa son las opciones estratégicas de Rusia, afirmó Putin, y añadió que la parte rusa se adhiere firmemente al principio de una sola China y siempre ha apoyado la posición de China sobre la cuestión de Taiwan.

Rusia está dispuesta a mantener estrechos intercambios de alto nivel con China, fortalecer la cooperación práctica en áreas como comercio, inversión, energía, agricultura, ciencia y tecnología, profundizar los intercambios entre pueblos y culturales en educación, cultura, juventud, turismo y otras áreas, y ampliar las connotaciones de la cooperación en la región del Lejano Oriente.

Imponer aranceles elevados es insensato e ilegal y solo tendrá consecuencias contraproducentes, afirmó Putin, y añadió que las dos partes deben fortalecer la coordinación y la cooperación en marcos multilaterales como las Naciones Unidas, la Organización de Cooperación de Shanghai y el BRICS, apoyar el proceso hacia un mundo multipolar, oponerse conjuntamente al unilateralismo, rechazar el abuso de las sanciones, resistir la confrontación de bloques y salvaguardar los intereses comunes de la comunidad internacional.
