title: Carney pidió a Trump no referirse a Canadá como estado 51, en medio de negociación comercial
content: “Tras haberme reunido con los dueños de Canadá durante la campaña electoral en los últimos meses, no está en venta. Nunca estará en venta”, afirmó Carney.
resumen:
El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país “nunca estará en venta”, durante una reunión en la Casa Blanca en medio de tensiones sobre aranceles y soberanía.

En su primer encuentro en la Oficina Oval, Trump insistió al recientemente elegido Carney que sería un “matrimonio maravilloso” si Canadá aceptara sus repetidos llamados para convertirse en el estado número 51 de Estados Unidos, un tema que genera fuertes fricciones.

Más tarde ambos líderes señalaron avances en las conversaciones, a pesar de que Carney afirmó haberle pedido a Trump en privado que dejara de insistir en que Canadá se anexione a Estados Unidos.

En la Oficina Oval, le había subrayado al magnate inmobiliario Trump que “hay lugares que nunca están en venta”.

“Tras haberme reunido con los dueños de Canadá durante la campaña electoral en los últimos meses, no está en venta. Nunca estará en venta”, afirmó Carney.

A lo que Trump replicó: “Nunca digas nunca”.

Carney, líder del Partido Liberal, de 60 años, ganó las elecciones canadienses del 28 de abril con la promesa de plantar cara al republicano Trump, de 78 años.

La relación de Canadá con Estados Unidos atraviesa turbulencias desde el regreso del magnate republicano a la Casa Blanca en enero, no sólo por la guerra comercial que desató, sino por sus extraordinarios llamamientos para que este país, importante aliado de la OTAN y socio comercial, pase a ser un estado estadounidense.

Tras la reunión de dos horas, ambos líderes adoptaron un tono positivo.

Carney declaró en rueda de prensa que las negociaciones comerciales son “complejas”, pero que sus conversaciones de dos horas con Trump fueron “muy constructivas”.

“Está dispuesto a negociar”, afirmó Carney, al ser preguntado sobre si Trump estaría dispuesto a reducir los aranceles.

También indicó que le había pedido a Trump que dejara de instar a Canadá a ser su estado número 51.

“Le dije que no era útil repetir esta idea, pero el presidente dirá lo que quiera”, declaró Carney en francés.

Por su parte, Trump afirmó que no hubo tensión durante la reunión, que calificó de “magnífica”.

“Queremos hacer lo correcto para nuestros respectivos pueblos”, sostuvo en un evento sobre el Mundial 2026, que Estados Unidos organizará junto con Canadá y México.

El encuentro de Carney con Trump era muy esperado tras las elecciones canadienses, durante las cuales el nuevo primer ministro aseguró que Estados Unidos nunca dominaría a Canadá.

Trump impuso aranceles a Canadá y México, salvo para los productos incluidos en el Tratado de libre comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC). Algunos sectores como el acero y el aluminio pagarán tarifas aduaneras de 25%.

Anteriormente, Carney fue gobernador del Banco de Canadá y del Banco de Inglaterra.

title: Esto dijo el presidente de CAF sobre Costa Rica y los aranceles de Trump
content: Estados Unidos es el principal socio comercial de Costa Rica; solo en 2024% se exportaron $9.401,9 millones a ese mercado.
resumen:
Sergio Díaz-Granados, presidente ejecutivo del Banco de Desarrollo de América Latina y el Caribe (CAF), considera que Costa Rica está en buena posición para ajustarse a las medidas comerciales de Estados Unidos.

En abril, el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, impuso una tasa arancelaria del 10% al país.

El Banco Central de Costa Rica redujo la proyección de crecimiento para este año a raíz de la guerra arancelaria desatada por el mandatario estadounidense.

Díaz-Granados afirmó que Costa Rica exporta productos de alto valor agregado al mercado estadounidense, lo cual facilita su capacidad de adaptación ante las nuevas condiciones comerciales.

El tratado de libre comercio entre Costa Rica y Estados Unidos ofrece una base útil para las negociaciones comerciales.

Estados Unidos es el principal socio comercial de Costa Rica. Durante 2024, el 47% de las exportaciones costarricenses tuvieron como destino esa nación. El año pasado, las exportaciones alcanzaron $19.900 millones; de ellos, $9.401,9 millones se dirigieron al mercado estadounidense.

Entre los principales productos destacan los dispositivos médicos, que representaron el 23% del total, seguidos por agujas, catéteres, cánulas, prótesis médicas, piña, café y banano.

El BCCR confirmó que los conflictos comerciales globales por la guerra arancelaria y por fenómenos climáticos afectarán la producción, pasando de un pronóstico para 2025 de 4,1%, en enero pasado, a una estimación de 3,6% en la actualización anunciada este 5 de mayo.

El 8 de abril, Manuel Tovar, ministro de Comercio Exterior, informó sobre la conformación de un equipo interinstitucional e indicó que se abrió un canal de diálogo con el sector exportador.

Díaz-Granados señaló que, para los demás países de América Latina, el panorama de las relaciones comerciales dependerá del grado de dependencia respecto al mercado estadounidense.

El presidente de CAF advirtió que el mundo atraviesa un cambio estructural en las normas comerciales.

El 2 de abril, el presidente estadounidense anunció impuestos recíprocos, con una tarifa del 10% para Costa Rica y otros países de América Latina. La medida entró en vigencia el 5 de abril.

A partir del 9 de abril, se aplicarían aranceles superiores al 10% para 57 países. No obstante, Trump anunció una pausa de 90 días para estas medidas y, en su lugar, implementó una tarifa universal del 10%.

title: Empresas y técnicos dominicanos saldrían afectados tras anuncio de aranceles del 100% a películas extranjeras
content: Las empresas y técnicos que brindan servicios a producciones internacionales en República Dominicana saldrían afectados tras el anuncio del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer un ar ...
resumen:
Empresas y técnicos dominicanos podrían verse afectados por el anuncio del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer un arancel del 100% a películas producidas fuera de Estados Unidos.

Hans García, director y productor cinematográfico, expresó que las empresas y técnicos que brindan servicios a producciones internacionales en el país podrían enfrentar dificultades.

El expresidente de la Asociación Dominicana de Profesionales de la Industria del Cine (Adocine) indicó que la imposición del arancel podría disuadir a las producciones extranjeras de filmar en República Dominicana, afectando la industria local y la economía nacional, además de la entrada de divisas.

Danilo Reynoso, productor de cine, expresó que el impacto inmediato sería sobre el artículo 39 de la Ley que incentiva las inversiones extranjeras.

Hollywood aporta gran parte de los más de 200 millones de dólares que en promedio entran cada año al país por este concepto, impactando directamente en la economía y generando cientos de empleos directos y miles indirectos.

Reynoso mencionó que Estados Unidos busca proteger su industria y a sus trabajadores.

title: CEOs are fretting about the extra costs of tariffs, particularly in trading with China
content: Chief executives are scrambling to translate President Trump’s trade war into tangible numbers they can share with analysts and investors.
resumen:
During earnings calls from March 15 through April 30, 245 of the 263 companies in the S&P 500 mentioned tariffs.

GE Vernova's chief executive Scott Strazik and chief financial officer Kenneth Parks said that the Trump tariffs are resulting in an additional $300 million to $400 million in inflationary costs this year for the company.

Thermo Fisher Scientific warned of a “$400 million headwind” in 2025 from the China tariff.

Boston Scientific chief executive Michael Mahoney forecast a $200 million hit to his company from the tariffs this year.

Hasbro is moving hundreds of items currently made in China to factories in other countries by the end of this year. Chief financial officer Gina Goetter said Hasbro executives hope to be making fewer than 40 percent of its products in China by 2026. Chief executive Chris Cocks said he is accelerating a $1 billion cost-savings plan as a result of the tariffs.

Boston Beer executives got peppered with questions about how tariffs are driving up expenses and driving down consumers’ thirst for Sam Adams.

At New Britain-based tool maker Stanley Black & Decker, executives said that tariff-related price increases are already showing up on hardware store shelves.

Michael Battles at Norwell-based Clean Harbors promised that tariff concerns are “a winner for us”.

At Yankee Candle parent Newell Brands, chief executive Chris Peterson boasted that his company is well-positioned to benefit from the craziness.

title: La hipocresía gringa que vive de los migrantes, pero los persigue como criminales
content: Donald Trump planea la mayor deportación de migrantes; miles arriesgan todo por el sueño americano mientras América Latina sufre éxodos y crisis ...

Se ha movilizado a la guardia nacional y a las fuerzas armadas en la frontera con México. El presidente de Colombia se ha negado a recibir a sus compatriotas deportados desde EE. UU. en aviones militares. Washington ha suspendido el servicio de visas en su consulado de Bogotá y amenaza con imponer aranceles a productos colombianos y cortar la ayuda humanitaria de la USAID. En el consulado de EE. UU. en Bogotá, cientos de personas hacen cola para obtener visas. Los solicitantes deben demostrar arraigo en el país, residencia fija, bienes raíces, cuentas bancarias y trabajo fijo. Se necesita esperar más de un año para una cita. Si se deniega la visa, puede ser una tragedia. Las estadísticas revelan que 1.556.273 colombianos residen en los EEUU (el 60% son ya ciudadanos estadounidenses y 20% indocumentados). Miles de migrantes tratan de cruzar el Darién. Donald Trump ha dado órdenes de reprimir a los clandestinos, cazándolos, encarcelándolos y deportándolos. En 2024 la administración Biden deportó 271.000 migrantes y se espera que suba a casi 500.000. Según la CEPAL en América Latina hay 380 millones de pobres, de los que 80 millones sobreviven en la indigencia absoluta. Se calcula que son aproximadamente 110 millones (66 millones en EE. UU.) de latinoamericanos los que residen legal o ilegalmente EE. UU., Canadá, Europa, Australia o Japón. Las remesas de los migrantes latinoamericanos cumplen una función imprescindible para mantener la paz social. En 2024 los migrantes enviaron desde EE.UU a sus países de origen la astronómica suma de 166.000 millones de dólares. El país que más recibió remesas fue México con 66.000 millones de dólares. Donald Trump señala a los migrantes como los principales culpables de la inseguridad y decadencia de EE.UU.

title: Trump Officials to Meet With Chinese Counterparts Amid Trade Standoff
content: Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, will discuss trade and economic matters with the officials this week.
resumen:
Top officials from the Trump administration will meet with their Chinese counterparts in Switzerland this week, the first formal meeting about trade between the United States and China since President Trump raised tariffs on Chinese imports to triple-digit levels last month.

Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, plan to meet with Chinese officials during a trip to Geneva, where they will discuss trade and economic matters.

He Lifeng, the vice premier for economic policy, would visit Switzerland from Friday to Monday and hold talks with Mr. Bessent. Mr. Bessent said on Fox News that the talks would be held on Saturday and Sunday.

In early April, Mr. Trump escalated tariffs on Chinese exports to a minimum of 145 percent.

The Trump administration has criticized China for its role in bringing fentanyl and ingredients to make the drug to the United States, as well as a bevy of unfair trade practices. Mr. Trump and his advisers have also censured China for failing to stick to the terms of a trade deal the president negotiated in his first term. China, in return, has called Mr. Trump’s tariffs “illegal and unreasonable.”

In the first quarter of this year, the U.S. share of imported goods from China fell to its lowest level in more than two decades.

Mr. Trump said the Chinese were eager for a meeting.

A spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Commerce said that U.S. officials had “continuously leaked information about adjusting tariff measures and actively conveyed information to China through various channels, hoping to talk with China on tariffs and other issues.”

“China has carefully evaluated the U.S. information,” the spokesperson said. “On the basis of fully considering global expectations, China’s interests and the calls of the U.S. industry and consumers, China has decided to agree to engage with the U.S.”

“If the United States wants to resolve the issue through negotiations,” the spokesperson added, “it must face up to the serious negative impact of unilateral tariff measures on itself and the world, face up to international economic and trade rules, fairness and justice, and rational voices from all walks of life, show sincerity in talks, correct its wrong practices, meet China halfway and resolve the concerns of both sides through equal consultation.”

Mr. Bessent and Mr. Greer are also expected to meet with the Swiss president, Karin Keller-Sutter, to discuss a potential trade deal.

Eswar Prasad, a former official at the International Monetary Fund who is now an economics professor at Cornell University, said that it was a “hugely positive development that the two sides are finally setting aside their posturing and commencing negotiations.”

title: Carney dice a Trump que Canadá 'nunca estará en venta'
content: El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país "nunca estará en venta", durante una reunión en la Casa Blanca en medio de tensiones sobre aranceles y ...
resumen: El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país "nunca estará en venta", durante una reunión en la Casa Blanca en medio de tensiones sobre aranceles y soberanía. En su primer encuentro en la Oficina Oval, Trump insistió al recientemente elegido Carney que sería un "matrimonio maravilloso" si Canadá aceptara sus repetidos llamados para convertirse en el estado número 51 de Estados Unidos, un tema que genera fuertes fricciones. Más tarde ambos líderes señalaron avances en las conversaciones, a pesar de que Carney afirmó haberle pedido a Trump en privado que dejara de insistir en que Canadá se anexione a Estados Unidos. Carney le había subrayado al magnate inmobiliario Trump que "hay lugares que nunca están en venta". "Tras haberme reunido con los dueños de Canadá durante la campaña electoral en los últimos meses, no está en venta. Nunca estará en venta", afirmó Carney. A lo que Trump replicó: "Nunca digas nunca". Carney, líder del Partido Liberal, de 60 años, ganó las elecciones canadienses del 28 de abril con la promesa de plantar cara al republicano Trump, de 78 años. La relación de Canadá con Estados Unidos atraviesa turbulencias desde el regreso del magnate republicano a la Casa Blanca en enero, no sólo por la guerra comercial que desató, sino por sus extraordinarios llamamientos para que este país, importante aliado de la OTAN y socio comercial, pase a ser un estado estadounidense. Tras la reunión de dos horas, ambos líderes adoptaron un tono positivo. Carney declaró en rueda de prensa que las negociaciones comerciales son "complejas", pero que sus conversaciones de dos horas con Trump fueron "muy constructivas". Carney afirmó que le había pedido a Trump que dejara de instar a Canadá a ser su estado número 51. "Le dije que no era útil repetir esta idea, pero el presidente dirá lo que quiera", declaró Carney en francés. Trump afirmó que no hubo tensión durante la reunión, que calificó de "magnífica". Trump impuso aranceles a Canadá y México, salvo para los productos incluidos en el Tratado de libre comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC). Algunos sectores como el acero y el aluminio pagarán tarifas aduaneras del 25%. Anteriormente, Carney fue gobernador del Banco de Canadá y del Banco de Inglaterra.

title: Despúes de los 100 días: ¿Quo Vadis, presidente Trump?
content: Las cosechas del presidente Trump en estos primeros 100 días son: Dispersión y lucha contra el mundo, incluso distanciamiento de países amigos, rápido descenso en su popularidad, incluso entre sus ...
resumen:
Después de los primeros 100 días del segundo gobierno del 47 presidente norteamericano, Donald Trump, que se cumplieron el pasado miércoles (20 de enero-30 de abril 2025). El presidente Trump celebró dicho acontecimiento subiendo en su Truth Social una fotografía vestido de papa con esta expresión: «Me gustaría ser papa. Esa sería mi opción número uno. Creo que sería un gran papa. Nadie lo haría mejor que yo”. El presidente Trump firmó 143 órdenes ejecutivas (decretos), 42 proclamaciones y 42 memorandos. Mediante esas disposiciones desató la guerra de los aranceles contra gobiernos y desde su poltrona presidencial expresó: “ésta vez gobierno al país y al mundo”. Economistas y escuelas de Economía vaticinan que “la guerra de los aranceles” induce a una delicada inflación combinada con recesión (estanflación) en EE.UU. EE.UU. está perdiendo la guerra ante China. El presidente Trump se abrió varios frentes de guerra con insultos, amenazas y drásticas decisiones que afectan directamente a múltiples sectores internos y externos.

1.- Amenazas y golpeos a más de 100 países, destacando los feroces ataques contra China, Panamá. Canadá, Groenlandia, México, Unión Europea, Venezuela, 2.- Fracaso de su promesa de detener la guerra Rusia-OTAN-Ucrania en “24 horas”. 3.- Apoyo económico y en armas para estimular la masacre contra niños, mujeres, ancianos y enfermos palestinos-Hamás en la Franja de Gaza. 4.- Supresión de fondos a varias ONGs y programas sociales nacionales e internacionales, 5.- Cierre de varios departamentos y cancelación de miles de empleados federales,. 6.- Desvinculación de organismos apéndices de la ONU. 7.-Amenazas, enfrentamientos y sanciones contra prestigiosas universidades norteamericanas suspendiéndoles asignaciones financieras. 8.- Fuertes enfrentamientos contra varios medios de comunicación y amenazas contra la libertad de expresión. 9.- Confrontaciones e insubordinación contra el poder judicial e irrespeto a la institucionalidad federal. 10.- Dramáticos desplomes en varias ocasiones de las bolsas de Wall Street con cuantiosas pérdidas multimillonarias. 11.- Ruptura unilateral de varios contratos y convenios con instituciones internacionales y otros países.

El presidente Trump, en estos 100 días, en ningún momento ha valorado ni se ha referido al vertiginoso fortalecimiento geopolítico de los países que se están aglutinando en el BRICS.

Acciones del presidente Trump en este período: 1.- Aumento de un 10 % de los aranceles. 2.- Subliminal mensaje para apropiación exclusiva de los derechos para uso y explotación de “nuestras tierras raras”. 3.- “Muy extraña indiferencia, ausencia y pasividad” ante la grave crisis por la que atraviesa Haití. 4.- Amenaza directa contra la autodeterminación y soberanía que se vislumbran en las “elocuentes declaraciones” de la asignada nueva embajadora: “En RD vamos a enfrentar el narcotráfico y la drogadicción y a detener los negocios y presencia de China.

Las cosechas del presidente Trump en estos primeros 100 días son: Dispersión y lucha contra el mundo, incluso distanciamiento de países amigos, rápido descenso en su popularidad, incluso entre sus fanáticos seguidores e importantes líderes del Partido Republicano y peligroso debilitamiento del dólar a nivel internacional.

title: República Dominicana a la espera de renegociación del arancel del 10% impuesto por EE. UU
content: República Dominicana sigue a la expectativa de que Estados Unidos decida renegociar la aplicación del arancel del 10 % .
resumen: República Dominicana espera la renegociación del arancel del 10% impuesto por Estados Unidos. El anuncio del arancel se hizo a principios de abril. El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump estableció 90 días de tregua. Tres ministros dominicanos viajaron a Estados Unidos para renegociar las condiciones arancelarias. Roberto Álvarez, ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, junto a los ministros de Industria, Comercio y Mipymes, y de Hacienda, se reunieron con Jamieson Greer, representante de Comercio de Estados Unidos. ADOEXPO ha planteado la necesidad de establecer acciones concretas para evitar desviaciones de comercio que perjudiquen las exportaciones dominicanas. Los 30 principales productos exportados hacia Estados Unidos representaron, en promedio, el 83 % del total exportado hacia ese mercado entre 2022 y 2024. La Asociación de Industrias de la República Dominicana (AIRD) advierte sobre el impacto del arancel del 10%. Mario Pujols, vicepresidente de AIRD, menciona que a las exportaciones mexicanas no se les está aplicando un arancel similar. Martín Valerio, director ejecutivo de la Cámara Minera y Petrolera de la República Dominicana (CAMIPE), propone un enfoque estratégico tripartito. El FMI prevé que la deuda pública mundial alcanzará el 95,1 % del PIB este año. José Manuel Salazar Xirinachs, secretario ejecutivo de la Cepal, indica que el impacto de la guerra arancelaria es "mucho peor" que la crisis financiera de 2008. La Cepal recortó sus proyecciones de crecimiento regional para este año en cuatro décimas hasta el 2 %.

title: After Trump tariffs, Malaysia delays local hikes in bid to fuel economic growth
content: Softening RON95, electricity and SST increases will deepen the fiscal deficit but shore up a slowing economy. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Malaysia is set to take a hit to its coffers due to the US import tariff regime. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is postponing measures such as tax hikes and subsidy cuts. Higher sales and services tax (SST) rates on a broader basket of items were due to be implemented on May 1, but the expansion has been postponed. A plan to cut subsidies for base-level RON95 petrol, initially scheduled for June, is set to be delayed or watered down. A minister admitted that it is "very difficult" to cut fuel subsidies now. A 24 per cent tariff against Malaysia was announced on April 2, with a 90-day pause put into effect. Datuk Seri Anwar said during a special May 5 parliamentary sitting that "there is a possibility that the US will reduce the reciprocal tariffs imposed on Malaysia" if ongoing negotiations are successful. The Budget 2025 projection for GDP growth in 2025, between 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent, may be revised. An electricity price hike of 14 per cent in July is expected. The government is under pressure to further subsidise the cost of the key utility beyond the RM6 billion allocated for the first half of 2025. Opposition leader Hamzah Zainudin urged the Anwar administration “to delay raising the price for RON95”. The SST expansion, which was set to rake in RM5 billion for the Treasury in 2025, is now due to be gazetted on June 1. Sources involved in stakeholder engagements told ST that more than 4,000 new items are expected to be hit by the tax. The inflationary impact from businesses passing on SST and electricity hikes to customers would also be compounded by a RON95 price increase. Teams in the Finance Ministry and central bank working on the fuel subsidy cut have not been making progress in work to revise earlier projections since April. Excluding those in the top 15 per cent income bracket from RON95 subsidies would save taxpayers RM8 billion annually. There is a proposal to exclude only the top fifth percentile from enjoying fuel subsidies under a two-tier pricing system. Abolishing diesel subsidies at petrol stations curbed 6.5 million litres of smuggled diesel daily. Annual savings from the measure are set to come up to RM7.5 billion. Oil prices have dropped from US$75 a barrel and dipping below US$60 on May 5. A per barrel price of US$55 could see RON95 costs match the RM2.05 tag at the pump. Socio-Economic Research Centre executive director Lee Heng Guie said that it immediately revised its forecast to 4 per cent, from 5 per cent, after the April 2 tariff announcement from Washington. Budget 2025 had pencilled in a fiscal deficit of 3.8 per cent of GDP. The government’s advance estimate for the first quarter was a lower-than-expected 4.4 per cent.

title: Trade Talks With China Have Not Started, Bessent Says
content: The Treasury secretary said that trade deals with other U.S. trading partners could be announced as soon as this week.
resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, dijo el martes que Estados Unidos podría anunciar acuerdos comerciales con los principales socios comerciales tan pronto como esta semana, pero que no han comenzado las negociaciones con China sobre los aranceles.

Los comentarios se produjeron cuando el Sr. Bessent testificaba ante un comité de la Cámara de Representantes y respondía preguntas sobre el estado de la economía estadounidense y la agenda comercial del presidente Trump. Los aranceles del Sr. Trump a China y a países de todo el mundo han provocado que los economistas reduzcan sus previsiones de crecimiento y adviertan sobre un nuevo episodio de inflación, pero el Sr. Bessent argumentó que las medidas conducirían en última instancia a que otros países redujeran sus barreras comerciales.

El secretario del Tesoro y el Sr. Trump han dicho durante semanas que muchas naciones estaban ansiosas por llegar a nuevos acuerdos comerciales que se anunciarían pronto, aunque hasta ahora no se ha materializado ninguno. El mes pasado, el Sr. Trump sugirió que también se había puesto en contacto con el líder de China, Xi Jinping, pero los funcionarios chinos insistieron en que no se estaban produciendo tales conversaciones.

El martes, el Sr. Bessent fue claro: "China, aún no hemos entablado negociaciones".

Las negociaciones con varias naciones comenzaron el mes pasado después de que el Sr. Trump impusiera un arancel universal del 10 por ciento a las importaciones de todos los países y aranceles adicionales que describió como "recíprocos" a docenas de ellos. Esos aranceles adicionales se han suspendido mientras se llevan a cabo las negociaciones.

No estaba claro si los acuerdos comerciales serían pactos formales o declaraciones de entendimiento mutuo sobre los términos comerciales revisados.

El Sr. Bessent trató de defender la política comercial del Sr. Trump, defendiendo los aranceles como necesarios para solucionar los desequilibrios comerciales. "Nuestro objetivo es un comercio justo para recuperar empleos de fabricación de precisión bien remunerados en los EE. UU.", dijo a los legisladores.

El Sr. Bessent también desestimó las previsiones que sugerían que el país se dirigía hacia una recesión. Dijo que los datos económicos no sugerían que la economía se estuviera contrayendo y predijo que los decepcionantes datos de crecimiento del primer trimestre se revisarían al alza.

title: El 63% de las empresas españolas planea aumentar sus inversiones en Iberoamérica
content: República Dominicana está entre los países en los que las empresas españolas mantendrán sus inversiones en 2025, no ven amenazas ni riesgos, es uno de los de menor complejidad en su sistema tributario ...
resumen: El 63% de las empresas españolas planea aumentar sus inversiones en Iberoamérica. República Dominicana está entre los países en los que las empresas españolas mantendrán sus inversiones en 2025, no ven amenazas ni riesgos, es uno de los de menor complejidad en su sistema tributario y destacan como ventaja su ubicación geográfica. La perspectiva de inversión en la región es menor a la del 2024, debido a la incertidumbre que plantean las medidas arancelarias de Donald Trump en el escenario comercial global. El resultado es 13 puntos menos que en 2024. El director del informe, el economista y profesor de IE University, Juan Carlos Martínez Lázaro, hizo la presentación en Casa de América, Madrid. El 63% de las empresas españolas planea aumentar sus inversiones en la región Iberoamericana, un puntaje de 13 por debajo de las perspectivas del 2024, según revela el XVII Informe 2025 Panorama de Inversión Española en Iberoamérica, presentado en la capital española por la Universidad IE, la firma de impuestos AUXADI y la aerolínea Iberia. El director del informe, el economista y profesor de IE University, Juan Carlos Martínez Lázaro, indica que el 30% de las empresas españolas apuesta por mantener sus inversiones en Iberoamérica, pero un 7% afirma que las disminuirán. El informe está basado en el resultado de una encuesta empresarial realizada a 105 empresas españolas entre diciembre 2024 y marzo 2025, y el cual ubica a México como el principal país de preferencia como tendencia de inversión, seguido de Colombia, Chile, Perú, Brasil, Paraguay y Costa Rica. En el resto de países se van a mantener las inversiones, incluyendo en República Dominicana. Martínez Lázaro indica que la guerra comercial ha cambiado radicalmente las perspectivas económicas en todo el planeta. El XVII Informe 2025: Panorama de Inversión de las empresas españolas en Iberoamérica indica que el 50% de las PYMES aumentará sus inversiones en la región. Aunque el 64% de las empresas españolas prevé que sus facturaciones aumentarán en la región iberoamericana, por primera vez ven un alto potencial de crecimiento en el mercado interno europeo. Solo un 39% de las empresas creen que sus facturaciones en la región pueden superar la de España y un 7% prevé aumentar sus ventas en la Unión Europea. México y Bogotá son los mercados preferidos. Respecto a la competencia de China solo un 20% cree que sí les afecta, un 25% la ven como un competidor importante, mientras el 55% no ve a China como un competidor significativo para sus negocios. Un 60% entiende que el aumento de sus inversiones se dará por crecimiento orgánico, un 37% por adquisiciones y orgánico y un 35% por adquisiciones. Respecto a las principales ventajas competitivas, un 67% ve el mercado interno atractivo; un 33% cree que es por mano de obra cualificada, 29.4% por acceso a materias primas, 28% por acuerdos de libre comercio con terceros, 25% por la competitividad del país y un 23% por la ubicación geográfica. México cumple con todas esas expectativas, Chile cumple cinco de ellas, Argentina y Brasil con dos, y. Colombia, República Dominicana y Panamá con una. RD es valorada por su ubicación geográfica. Las empresas españolas manifestaron preocupación por las altas tasas de interés y la volatilidad cambiaria en la región, a lo que se suma el marco legal y regulatorio, más que el porcentaje de inflación en las economías. Juan Carlos Martínez Lázaro, junto al embajador de México en España, la diretora comercial de Iberia, ejecutivos de AUXADI, el director de Civitatis, el diretor de Casa de América y el director del IE University. De igual modo, califican como amenaza y riesgo para sus inversiones la inestabilidad política, volatilidad del tiempo de cambio, inseguridad jurídica, desaceleración económica e inestabilidad social. En una escala del 1 al 5, República Dominicana quedó con una puntuación de 3.32, solo superada por Argentina y Uruguay que quedaron en 3.59 y 3.33, respectivamente en un análisis a 19 países iberoamericanos. En cuanto a perspectivas de crecimiento económico, RD quedó por encima de Brasil, Perú, México, Colombia, Panamá, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Ecuador, Bolivia, Nicaragua, Cuba y Venezuela. RD está también entre los países con menor complejidad tributaria, al quedar en una puntuación de 2.90 en una calificación del 1 al 5. Las empresas españolas invierten en Iberoamérica en 18 sectores, que van desde la construcción, concesiones, ingenierías, arquitectura; un 17% en industrias de software, tecnologías y “starturps” tecnológicas, 10% en industria y manufacturas, 9% en energía, 5% en automóviles, componentes y construcción ferroviaria, 5% en servicios bancarios y 35% en otros servicios. title: Trump says US should to stop ‘subsidising’ Canada as trade talks continue
content: The US leader says it’s hard to justify the US$200 billion deficit, including defence spending benefiting the nation.
resumen: WASHINGTON: President Donald Trump on Tuesday said the US should stop “subsidising” Canada, as he hosted the country’s recently reelected premier Mark Carney for talks in Washington. Canada has been caught up in the new administration’s stop-start tariff rollout, which has hit goods not covered under an existing free trade arrangement with levies of up to 25%. Canada’s autos, steel, and aluminum exports have also been hit by the tariffs. “We have a tremendous deficit with Canada,” Trump told reporters during an event at the White House, with Carney seated just a few feet away. “It’s hard to justify subsidising Canada to the tune of maybe US$200 billion a year,” he said, adding: “We protect Canada militarily, and we always will.” The US’ trade deficit with Canada was US$63.3 billion last year, according to the US trade representative’s office. The far higher figure of US$200 billion often cited by Trump also takes into account how much US defence spending benefits Canada, a member of the Trump transition team told CNN in mid-January, ahead of his return to office. Returning to the issue of trade, Trump said America’s northern neighbour would soon have to “take care of itself economically.” “We don’t really want cars from Canada, and we put tariffs on cars from Canada,” he said. “And at a certain point, it won’t make economic sense for Canada to build those cars.” “We really don’t want Canadian steel, and we don’t want Canadian aluminium and various other things, because we want to be able to do it ourselves,” he added. The White House previously estimated that around 38% of Canadian imports to the US and around half of all Mexican imports, are covered by the existing US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) and are currently not subject to the sweeping tariffs. A large part of Canada’s US imports not covered by the USMCA exemption are energy products, which currently face a lower 10% tariff rate. The USMCA is due for review next year.

title: Mattel Says It’s Going to Raise Prices After Trump Says Americans Don’t Need So Many Dolls
content: As far as its efforts to address tariffs, Kreiz said that the company is also focused on diversifying its global supply chain to reduce its reliance on China. The Mattel chief claimed in the ...
resumen: Mattel CEO Ynon Kreiz cast doubt on the notion that Mattel might move its manufacturing to the United States in light of President Trump’s tariffs on Chinese goods in an appearance on CNBC’s “Squawk Box” on Tuesday. Mattel does see rising prices in the US. Kreiz cited three key strategies the company is deploying to mitigate the costs of Trump’s trade war, with “pricing action,” among them. Mattel withdrew its annual financial forecast, explaining in its first quarter earnings report that, “Given the volatile macroeconomic environment and evolving U.S. tariff landscape, it is difficult to predict consumer spending and Mattel’s U.S. sales in the remainder of the year and holiday season.” Mattel also said it had raised its cost savings target for the year from $60 million to $80 million, part of which would be achieved by cutting promotions and discounts. The company also laid off more than one hundred employees from its Headquarters in El Segundo, CA, at the end of March. Kreiz said that the company is also focused on diversifying its global supply chain to reduce its reliance on China. In two years, no single country will represent more than 25% of Mattel’s sourcing. Mattel also imports products (which include Barbies, Hot Wheels, and American Girl Dolls) from Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. Those countries were also the targets of reciprocal tariffs announced by the Trump administration in early April before being paused for 90 days. President Trump addressed the impact tariffs would have on the toy industry (80% of global toy production takes place in China), saying in a cabinet meeting that, “Well, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls, you know? And maybe the two dolls will cost a couple of bucks more than they would normally.” Kreiz emphasized that Mattel is committed to producing a steady supply of product at a “wide range of affordable price points.” Roth analyst Eric Handler told CNBC that Mattel expects to keep between 40% and 50% of its products under $20. The Toy Association, a trade group representing the US toy industry, has pushed hard for an exemption from Trump’s tariffs since they were announced. Kreiz expressed his support for the group’s advocacy in the interview, saying that toys are “an essential part of children’s lives.” Kreiz came to Mattel in 2018 from Maker Studios. The Barbie brand posted its best full-year sales results of all time in 2021 under Krez’s leadership. Last week, speaking to reporters during a cabinet meeting, President Trump said that “maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls,” this Christmas season.

title: Trump's tariffs are hurting Tennesseans and the local economy. Here's how | Opinion
content: From job losses and increased costs related to reduced exports, Tennesseans will only be harmed by Trump's tariffs ...
resumen: Economists widely disagree with tariffs as effective economic policy, citing potential harm to efficient industries and overall economic growth. Tariffs are also likely to raise consumer prices and cause job losses in sectors reliant on imports. Tariffs can negatively impact Tennessee's manufacturing and export-heavy economy, affecting industries like automotive and medical equipment. Over 1,700 economists disagree with tariffs, seeing no credible economic justification for them, and warning that they will only prop up inefficient producers at the expense of more efficient industries. This will undermine economic efficiency, employment, and wage growth in Tennessee. Economists aren’t convinced by any of the three justifications the Trump Administration advances for tariffs. If Trump’s goal is job protectionism, then tariffs must be high enough to force Americans to buy American. If revenue is the goal, then tariffs must be low enough so Americans will still pay the tax, which means they will not protect American jobs. If negotiation towards free trade is the goal, then neither job nor revenue objectives will be achieved. Tariffs protect some American jobs in a few sectors by destroying far more American jobs in other sectors. Dockworkers, truckers, and delivery drivers are the first Americans to lose their jobs under tariffs. Next comes job losses at American firms that import inputs, such as materials, parts, and compounds, to produce goods and services. Nearly 60% of our imports are inputs, so tariffs will substantially raise costs for American companies. These costs will be passed along to consumers, resulting in fewer sales and, thus, job loss. Steel tariffs to protect jobs in the steel industry caused massive job losses in the American automobile, motorcycle, and farming equipment sectors. Tariffs slash foreign investment in the American economy. Tariffs make American goods and services more expensive, hurting our exporting industries and reducing foreign investment in our country. Retaliatory tariffs, which can be expected, only serve to amplify these losses. Tariffs are a tax paid by American consumers. Tariffs tend to be a regressive tax because a set tax will fall heavier on the budgets of the poor than the wealthy. No credible estimates come even close to raising enough revenue. America has some of the highest tariffs and non-tariff barriers among our major trading partners. Trump started negotiations not by lowering our tariffs to match our trading partners but by jacking them up across the board. He ripped up previous trade agreements, including one he signed and declared “the fairest, most balanced, and beneficial trade agreement” ever. Countries like India, China, and Vietnam—with per capita GDPs of only $2,500, $12,500, and $4,300 (compared to nearly $83,000 for the US)—won’t be buying our automobiles anytime soon. Tennessee’s economy, heavily tied to manufacturing and exports, suffers from these ripple effects. The state exported nearly $40 billion in goods in 2024, including $4.25 billion in medical instruments, $2.63 billion in automobiles, and $2.26 billion in computers. Roughly 1/5th of Tennessee’s jobs are driven by international trade. Trump’s 2025 “Liberation Day” tariffs can be expected to slash exports, raise input costs, and reduce competitiveness for firms like Nissan in Smyrna, Jack Daniels in Lynchburg, or Bridgestone in La Vergne. A recent Goldman Sachs report estimated that a 10% tariff alone could destroy five U.S. jobs for every job created, even without retaliation. The U.S. is manufacturing more than it ever has in inflation-adjusted terms. We are the second-largest exporter of manufactured goods in the world and the largest exporter of services. Automation is allowing people worldwide to move out of mundane, low-skilled jobs. Daniel J. Smith is the Director of the Political Economy Research Institute and Professor of Economics at Middle Tennessee State University.

title: Strategic Opportunities: How Does Putin Benefit from Trump’s Presence in the White House?
content: The presence of U.S. President Donald Trump in the White House may represent a golden opportunity for Russia to achieve its strategic interests, both ...
resumen:
The presence of U.S. President Donald Trump in the White House may represent a golden opportunity for Russia to achieve its strategic interests, both in its immediate regional surroundings and in seeking to restore part of its lost role on the global stage. This arises from both presidents speaking the same language of “interests,” which explains their political behavior and motivations for foreign action, alongside direct interests for Moscow under Trump’s administration, contrasting with his predecessor, President Joe Biden, who sought to isolate Russia after its war on Ukraine in February 2022. Russia’s vision of its role cannot be viewed in isolation from the realization of its declining comprehensive capabilities compared to both the United States and China, and its practical inability to exercise that role, as reflected in its weakened economy and the depletion of its military machinery after nearly three years of continuous fighting.

Trump and Putin share traits that characterize their self-perception, the status of their countries, and the global order, including “Over-leadership” with Contextual Differences, Nationalism as a Major Driving Force for Foreign Policy, and A Diminished View of Multilateral International Institutions. These personal traits create space for a “psychological convergence” that allows Trump and Putin to operate in a manner highlighted by Trump’s opening of back channels for understanding with his Russian counterpart and sending his personal envoy, Steve Witkoff, to meet with Putin four times between January and April 2025, with the Russian president welcoming these meetings. Yuri Ushakov, Putin’s assistant for foreign policy, described these meetings as “useful and constructive.” Trump and Putin differ in the depth of their strategic thinking and movement on the global chessboard. While Trump prefers to rely on “deals” rather than “ideology” or “long-term strategies” to achieve gains, stemming from his background as a successful businessman; Putin operates according to a specific strategy focused on rapid gains with an emphasis on long-term goals, which include addressing the root causes of the conflict in Ukraine, obstructing NATO’s expansion near Russian borders, and reshaping the global order so that Russia plays a significant role in it, especially concerning Europe, which Moscow considers its main sphere of influence.

Russia’s interests under Trump’s administration can be summarized as follows: Neutralizing Ukraine According to Putin’s Ideological Vision, which primarily hinges on recognition of Moscow’s sovereignty over Crimea, occupied in 2014, retaining territories occupied in Eastern Ukraine since the onset of the war in 2022, including Luhansk Oblast and parts of Donetsk, Kherson, and Zaporizhzhia. Halting NATO’s Expansion Along Russian Borders. Lifting Sanctions Imposed on the Russian Economy Since 2014.

Moscow sees many opportunities presented by Trump’s presence in the White House, allowing for a greater ability to pursue an influential global role, as follows: Trump’s Policies and the Fracture of the Western Deterrence Camp, Undermining the International Order Led by Washington, and Reshaping Global Geopolitical Balances to Expand Russia’s Influence. Moscow is betting on two main factors to achieve this goal: the impact of Trump’s presence and the U.S. focus on countering the Chinese threat. Russia has worked to enhance its image as an independent power from the West and sought to strengthen its strategic alliances, foremost among them its relationship with China, and has worked to bolster its relations with North Korea. Additionally, Russia has sought to form new alliances with countries like India, and has not overlooked building partnerships with countries in Africa and Latin America. The competition with Washington over the rich oil and gas resources of the Arctic cannot be ignored, where Russia controls nearly half the region’s reserves.

The aforementioned opportunities face several challenges that affect Russia’s effectiveness in fulfilling the role it aspires to, especially when compared to the United States and China. Russia is suffering from a decline in its capabilities, as evidenced by the weakness of its industrial base compared to major European countries like Germany and France, as well as its economy’s reliance on exporting oil and gas. The Russian army’s inability to decisively conclude the war in Ukraine. These challenges are connected to the unintended consequences of the rift in U.S.-European relations, which has prompted Europe to rearm itself, as highlighted by the EU representatives’ agreement at a summit held for this purpose in Brussels in March 2025 to mobilize about 800 billion euros for European rearmament. Russia’s continued ambition for a global role hinges on two main factors: Putin’s continued rule and Moscow’s ability to overcome the challenges resulting from its increasing dependence on China and North Korea to offset its losses in the Ukrainian war, along with facing Western sanctions.

Russia recognizes that Trump’s return to the White House opens a rare strategic window for repositioning itself in the international system and achieving several of its vital interests, both in Ukraine and in reshaping global balances.

title: How will Canada’s new prime minister affect New York?
content: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has a mandate to fight back against the Trump administration’s attacks on our northern neighbor – and New York could be caught in the middle.
resumen:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has a mandate to fight back against the Trump administration’s attacks on our northern neighbor – and New York could be caught in the middle.

The trade war between America and Canada has already had significant impacts on New York industries from agriculture to manufacturing, and if the situation spirals, especially following Carney’s meeting with President Donald Trump on Tuesday, it could make things even worse for the state.

Chris Kirkey, director of the Center for the Study of Canada and Institute on Québec Studies at SUNY Plattsburgh, believes that Carney won’t let things escalate.

Kirkey told City & State: “Mark Carney is committed to trade with New York and trade with the United States. He's not a protectionist. He's one who believes in the value of markets, but particularly free markets.”

Assembly Member Billy Jones said that even if Carney does manage to mend fences and repair the way that some Canadians are beginning to view the U.S. and New York, much of the economic damage is done.

Jones said that Canadian officials understand the situation that New York is in, but new policies in response to the trade war, like limiting barriers for interprovincial commerce and labor supply, are already in motion.

Gov. Kathy Hochul and other governors in the northeast also invited Canadian officials to the U.S. in a bid to strengthen cross border ties.

Rep. Josh Riley, who represents a large rural district in upstate New York, is hopeful that Carney will recognize the situation and negotiate for a more equitable trade agreement.

Riley said: “My hope is that this summer, when the United States, Mexico and Canada trade agreement is up for review, there's an opportunity there to renegotiate some parts of it in a way that does two things: first, provide certainty and support for Upstate New York's farmers, and then second, brings good manufacturing jobs back home.”

Chris Kirkey said: “I think New York has to just once again remind folks that this relationship is really a positive one for New York state.”

title: Effects of Trump’s trade war loom over the Port of Virginia
content: Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United State economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.
resumen:
The Port of Virginia supports 1.29 million jobs, employs 565,000 people in Virginia and accounts for over $100 billion added to the national economy, 2021 data says.

Local experts and officials don’t have a clear picture of how the Trump administration’s tariff policy will affect the Port of Virginia and the many thousands of jobs connected to it, but ports across the country are bracing for a significant slowdown in traffic.

Impacts will be felt between May and July, according to Vinod Agarwal, a professor of economics at Old Dominion University and deputy director for ODU’s Dragas Center for Economic Analysis and Policy.

The tariffs are levied on “just about every trade lane we have,” said Joe Harris, a spokesperson for the Port of Virginia.

Port of Virginia CEO Stephen Edwards said, “very plainly, it’s hard to know.”

The port had its second-busiest March on record, according to Harris.

Agarwal said is “simply because everyone knew the tariffs would be taking place in April and if you’re in the business of importing goods you want to make sure they arrive in time before the tariffs go into effect.”

Tariffs should lead to a decrease in imports at almost all U.S. ports, not just the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

The effect of the tariffs has not yet been seen in as much detail as is likely to be seen in the next couple of months.

The tariffs will lead to increases in prices, the higher prices will result in decreased demand for these products, so we should see a decline in imports which will of course affect the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United States economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.

Gene Seroka, executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, which had an economic impact of $311 billion in 2021, said they’ve seen roughly 33% drop off in their import volume over the last few weeks.

Apollo Global Management estimates U.S. consumers could start seeing shortages on store shelves by mid- to late-May, that there will be layoffs in the trucking and retail industries in late May and early June, and that there will be a recession by this summer.

title: ‘Tariff challenge could make Asian economies resilient’
content: The uncertainty created by the Trump administration on global trade and economic growth could still create opportunities for Asian economies if they remain on the reform path and dispel any sense of ...
resumen: Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Masato Kanda stated that the uncertainty created by the Trump administration on global trade and economic growth could still create opportunities for Asian economies if they remain on the reform path and dispel any sense of complacency from their economic successes. Higher US tariffs imposed on Asian goods have created much uncertainty. The region is more resilient now than before, owing to not only the benefits of open trade but also greater interconnectedness. Kanda believes this is a good opportunity for Asian and Pacific countries to turn these challenges into the opportunity to make their economies more resilient, stronger, and open, and interconnected in the region and with their new partners, and that they probably need to continue the reform path. ADB can help the region by drawing from its “massive firepower” to fight off the uncertainties that Trump’s tariff war brings, including countercyclical financial assistance or the debt management support in the region, and a trade supply chain enhancement program. The key to creating opportunities amid uncertainties include boosting domestic demand, diversifying industries and trade partners as well as supply chain destinations. ADB has 1,000 additional people utilizing this firepower and together with the partnership with the countries they will help them reform to the more diverse economy and they are deepening their capital and financial markets. Kanda reiterated his points on the uncertainties facing Asia and the Pacific and how this can be an opportunity for a resilient and sustainable future at the ADB’s 58th Annual Meeting of the Board of Governors. External shocks, debt burdens, and climate change weigh heavily on the people and economies of the region. Growth remains solid, trade and economic integration are deepening, supply chains are diversifying, and digital connectivity and innovation are accelerating. Italian Minister of Economy and Finance Giancarlo Giorgetti and Governor of the Bank of Italy and Chair of the ADB Board of Governors Fabio Panetta also spoke at the Opening Session, emphasizing Italy’s partnership with ADB. ADB has been working to solve complex challenges together with its members and partners, both regional and nonregional. ADB is increasing its financing for food and nutrition security in Asia and the Pacific to $40 billion by 2030 as more people struggle with surging food prices and the threats of climate change. This is a $26-billion increase from the $14 billion average between 2022 and 2025. The spike in food prices has been forcing families to choose between spending for meals and non-food items like transportation. The increase in financing from ADB will help feed 270 million people in the region and increase food production and agriculture-linked jobs.

title: Ford Says Tariffs Will Cost Company $1.5 Billion in 2025
content: Ford is less affected by President Trump’s 25 percent tariffs on vehicles than other automakers because most of the vehicles it sells in the United States are made in the country. General Motors said ...
resumen:
Ford Motor dijo el lunes que las políticas arancelarias de la administración Trump probablemente reducirían sus ganancias de 2025, antes de intereses e impuestos, en aproximadamente $1.5 mil millones. La compañía también abandonó su pronóstico para el año, diciendo que predecir el futuro se había vuelto demasiado difícil.

Ford se ve menos afectado por los aranceles del 25 por ciento del presidente Trump sobre los vehículos que otros fabricantes de automóviles porque la mayoría de los vehículos que vende en los Estados Unidos se fabrican en el país. General Motors dijo la semana pasada que los aranceles aumentarían sus costos entre $4 mil millones y $5 mil millones este año.

"Creemos que estamos bien posicionados para adaptarnos a los cambios que los aranceles están impulsando en nuestra industria", dijo la directora financiera de Ford, Sherry House, en una conferencia telefónica.

La compañía dijo que las cambiantes políticas arancelarias de la administración tenían el potencial de interrumpir las cadenas de suministro automotrices, y podrían obligar a otras naciones a imponer aranceles de represalia a las exportaciones estadounidenses. También señaló una mayor incertidumbre en las políticas fiscales y de emisiones de la administración Trump.

"Consideramos prudente suspender nuestra guía para todo el año", dijo la Sra. House.

Ford dijo anteriormente que esperaba ganancias para 2025, antes de intereses e impuestos, de $7 mil millones a $8.5 mil millones.

La administración Trump ha impuesto aranceles del 25 por ciento a los vehículos y autopartes importados. Ha aumentado los aranceles sobre el acero y el aluminio importados, que se utilizan ampliamente en automóviles y camiones.

Esos y otros aranceles impuestos por el Sr. Trump significan un cambio importante en la política comercial de Estados Unidos, especialmente en lo que respecta al comercio entre Estados Unidos, Canadá y México. Durante décadas, los automóviles y las autopartes se han enviado por toda América del Norte con pocos o ningún arancel.

Ford fabrica algunos vehículos en México, incluido un modelo eléctrico clave, el Mustang Mach-E, y planea comenzar a fabricar camionetas de servicio pesado en Canadá en 2026. La Sra. House dijo que el fabricante de automóviles no estaba considerando cambiar sus planes de camiones de servicio pesado.

La compañía también informó que sus ganancias en los primeros tres meses del año cayeron a $471 millones, de $1.3 mil millones un año antes. Ford culpó a la disminución de las ventas de vehículos porque había pausado la producción en algunas fábricas para prepararse para nuevos modelos e hizo otros cambios destinados a reducir los inventarios de automóviles y camiones sin vender.

Sus ingresos en el trimestre disminuyeron un 5 por ciento, a $40.7 mil millones. Ford redujo su pérdida en vehículos eléctricos a $849 millones de una pérdida de $1.3 mil millones un año antes. Las ganancias de la venta de vehículos convencionales de combustión interna cayeron a $96 millones de $901 millones. Las ganancias de la venta de camiones comerciales y servicios relacionados disminuyeron a $1.3 mil millones de $3 mil millones.

title: 100 days in: Here's where President Trump's policies have mirrored Project 2025
content: He distanced himself on the campaign trail, but here's where Trump's policies align with the conservative playbook.
resumen:
Despite distancing himself from Project 2025 on the campaign trail, there have been substantial parallels between the initiative and President Donald Trump’s second administration.

There was a lot of conversation surrounding Project 2025 in the months leading up to the November election, largely due to its calls to significantly reduce and reshape the scope of the federal government.

At the September debate against former Vice President Kamala Harris, Trump said he had “nothing to do with Project 2025.” On his Truth Social platform, Trump also repeatedly posted about having nothing to do with Project 2025, and in a July post he called parts of it “ridiculous and abysmal.”

Now, 100 days into his second administration, nearly 45% of Trump's executive orders closely mirror policy recommendations Project 2025 advocates for, according to an analysis by the Hearst Television Data Team.

Project 2025 is an initiative spearheaded by conservative think tank The Heritage Foundation that gives guidance for what policies the next conservative president should carry out. The initiative began in 2022, and its main policy guidebook — the 922-page “Mandate for Leadership: The Conservative Promise” — was published a year later.

In order to determine if there were overlaps between Trump administration policies and Project 2025, the Hearst Television Data Team analyzed how many executive orders align with policy recommendations in the “Mandate for Leadership.” Any executive order involving tariffs was excluded from the analysis due to Project 2025’s conflicting recommendations on the issue.

Of the 126 non-tariff executive orders, 56 contain policy recommendations that closely mirror Project 2025.

One of the largest areas where there is overlap between Project 2025 and Trump’s executive orders is on the issue of government reform, accountability and deregulation. While Project 2025 does not explicitly call for the creation of the Department of Government Efficiency, it does advocate for many of the government workforce and reduction changes that Trump’s executive orders carry out.

In his first 100 days, Trump has brought back Schedule F, making it easier to fire federal employees, eliminated DEI from the federal government, reinstated service members with backpay who were discharged under former President Joe Biden’s COVID-19 vaccine mandate, and called for agencies to cut back on costs. All of these actions were advocated for in Project 2025.

On March 30, Trump issued an Executive Order to begin the dismantling of the Department of Education — one of the policies in Project 2025 that made a lot of headlines before the election.

Trump and Project 2025 have also aligned on various policies to boost domestic energy production, strengthen immigration enforcement, and implement deregulations.

The two do differ on a couple of key issues. Project 2025 calls for an outright ban on TikTok, citing national security risks. Trump has yet to make a final call on TikTok, but has delayed its banning in the U.S.

Project 2025 also gives conflicting advice regarding tariffs. Author Kent Lassman laid out an argument for free trade that critiqued tariffs. Author Peter Navarro — who ultimately Trump hired as his senior counselor for trade and manufacturing — argued for tariffs to strengthen domestic manufacturing.

While ideas are shared between Project 2025 and the executive orders Trump has signed, it is unclear the extent to which one influenced the other. Project 2025 was created by a think tank whose aim is to influence political policy. It is just one of many similar proposals created by conservative policy groups — unique largely in how it captured the media’s attention last summer and Trump’s claim he had “nothing to do with it.”

Many authors of Project 2025 are now members of Trump’s top team of officials. Budget Director Russ Vought, FCC Chair Brendan Carr and Navarro were all authors of Project 2025. Additionally, CIA Director John Ratcliffe, Border Czar Tom Homan, and Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Paul Atkins were all among the contributors to Project 2025.

title: Rupiah Strengthens as US-China Trade Tension Eases
content: The Indonesian rupiah has started to regain ground amid signs of easing trade tensions between the United States and China, analysts said on Friday.
resumen:
The Indonesian rupiah has started to regain ground amid signs of easing trade tensions between the United States and China, analysts said Friday, May 2.

Rully Nova, an economist at Bank Woori, attributed the rupiah's strengthening to improved global sentiment following a thaw in tariff disputes between the world's two largest economies.

Rully said the rupiah is expected to close stronger today, in the Rp16,550–Rp16,450 range, driven by cooling global tensions — particularly China's softer stance and willingness to reopen trade talks with the U.S., as quoted by state news agency Antara.

According to Rully, China's readiness to return to the negotiating table stems from its ongoing reliance on U.S. industrial raw materials. He also noted that China's economic recovery remains heavily dependent on exports, as its domestic property sector has yet to bounce back from previous downturns.

Rully said there are no winners in a tariff war — both the U.S. and China end up losing.

Looking ahead, Rully expects the two countries to forge a mutually beneficial relationship in trade and investment, which could help stabilize market sentiment further.

On the domestic front, Indonesia's Central Statistics Agency (BPS) reported a monthly inflation rate of 1.17 percent in April 2025 — a sign that the recent deflationary trend may have run its course, as the broader economy shows signs of entering an expansionary phase.

Rully added that this gives Bank Indonesia some room to cut its benchmark interest rate.

Lukman Leong, a currency and commodity strategist at Doo Financial Futures, warned that the rupiah could weaken following remarks by U.S. President Donald Trump, who suggested that tariff agreements with multiple trading partners were in the works.

Leong said the rupiah may depreciate as the US dollar strengthens broadly in response to Trump's comments on potential deals with India, South Korea, Japan, and China.

Adam Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics (PIIE), recently placed the odds of a U.S. recession at 65 percent, citing policy uncertainty as a key risk.

Gary Clyde Hufbauer, a non-resident senior fellow at PIIE, echoed that view, predicting a likely recession in the second half of 2025. He pointed to weakening consumer sentiment and growing business uncertainty, which are expected to weigh on second-quarter GDP growth.

The Kobeissi Letter, a financial publication, reported that the US economy contracted by 0.3 percent in the first quarter of 2025 — well below market expectations of 0.3 percent growth. This marked the first and steepest contraction since the second quarter of 2022 and has heightened concerns that a recession is now the base-case scenario for the rest of the year.

Leong noted that investor focus has shifted toward tariff developments.

Back in Jakarta, the rupiah briefly weakened at the start of Friday's trading session, slipping 25 points or 0.15 percent to Rp16,602 per US dollar from Rp16,577. But by the close of the day, the currency had rallied, gaining 139 points or around 0.84 percent to end at Rp16,438 per dollar.

Similarly, Bank Indonesia's Jakarta Interbank Spot Dollar Rate (JISDOR) on Friday afternoon showed the rupiah strengthening to Rp16,493 per dollar, up from Rp16,679 the previous day.

As of Monday, May 5, the rupiah climbed further to Rp16,406 per dollar, a 0.19 percent appreciation from the prior session.

Most other Asian currencies also posted gains: the Thai baht rose 0.15 percent, the Malaysian ringgit strengthened 0.35 percent, and the Japanese yen edged up 0.16 percent.

title: Canadá advierte sobre daños en ese país y Estados Unidos si aplican aranceles al sector audiovisual
content: La industria audiovisual y las autoridades canadienses criticaron este lunes la intención del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a las producciones realizadas en el extra ...
resumen:
La industria audiovisual y las autoridades canadienses criticaron la intención del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a las producciones realizadas en el extranjero y advirtieron que causarían graves daños en Canadá y Estados Unidos.

El presidente de la Asociación de Productores de Canadá (APC), Reynolds Mastin, señaló que la propuesta “causará una significante disrupción y dificultades económicas en los sectores de producción a ambos lados de la frontera entre Canadá y Estados Unidos”.

Según Mastin, las palabras de Trump “subrayan la enorme importancia de garantizar que Canadá cuente con una industria mediática nacional fuerte e independiente”.

Muchas películas de Hollywood además de series de televisión y producciones de plataformas de retransmisión por internet son filmados en Canadá gracias a las ventajas económicas que el país ofrece a los estudios.

La provincia de Columbia Británica es el tercer lugar de Norteamérica donde más producciones se filman, solo por detrás de California y Nueva York.

La provincia de Ontario, donde se sitúa Toronto, es el cuarto destino.

En Toronto se han rodado películas de Hollywood como ‘La forma del agua’ (2017), ‘Suicide Squad’ (2016), ‘Brokeback Mountain’ (2005) o ‘Chicago’ (2002), además de series como ‘Suits’ (2011-2019).

En Vancouver se han producido filmes como ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ (2015), ‘Deadpool’ (2016) o ‘Jumanji’ (1995).

El sindicato de actores de Canadá (ACTRA) señaló que en 2023-2024 el sector audiovisual contribuyó con 11,000 millones de dólares canadienses (8,000 millones de dólares estadounidenses o 7,000 millones de euros) al Producto Interior Bruto (PIB) de Canadá.

En Toronto, las producciones generaron 2,600 millones de dólares canadienses en 2022.

La alcaldesa de Toronto, Olivia Chow, declaró que el sector emplea a 30.000 personas en la ciudad y afirmó que los aranceles sería “devastadores”.

El ministro de Desarrollo Económico de Ontario, Vic Fedeli, afirmó que los aranceles propuestos por Trump son un “asalto directo” a la provincia.

US President Donald Trump said on Sunday that his top priority was to secure a fair trade deal with China.

Signs of a de-escalation in the trade war with China appeared after U.S. officials engaged in a flurry of meetings with trading partners after April 2, when Trump imposed a 10% tariff on most countries and suspended higher levies on many trading partners for 90 days.

The duties are now scheduled to kick in on July 8.

He has also imposed 25% tariffs on autos, steel and aluminium, 25% levies on imports from Canada and Mexico and 145% tariffs on China.

In his latest move, Trump imposed a 100% tariff on movies produced outside the United States and sent into the country.

A cornerstone of Trump’s vision includes a phased rollout of universal tariffs on all U.S. imports.

Trump had tasked his economics team with devising plans for reciprocal tariffs on every country that taxes U.S. imports and to counteract non-tariff barriers such as vehicle safety rules that exclude U.S. autos, as well as value-added taxes that increase their cost.

MEXICO AND CANADA: The two countries were the largest trading partners of the U.S. in 2024 through November, with Mexico ranked first. Trump’s new 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada took effect on March 4 as a retaliation for migration and fentanyl trafficking.

The tariffs included a 25% levy on most goods from Mexico and Canada, along with a 10% duty on Canada’s energy imports.

Canada primarily exports crude oil and other energy goods, as well as cars and auto parts within the North American auto manufacturing chain.

Mexico also exports various goods to the U.S. in the industrial and auto sectors.

Canada hit back with 25% tariffs on C$30 billion ($21.13 billion) worth of U.S. imports, including orange juice, peanut butter, beer, coffee, appliances and motorcycles.

The Canadian government added that it would impose additional tariffs on C$125 billion of U.S. goods if Trump’s tariffs were still in place in 21 days, with the potential inclusion of vehicles, steel, aircraft, beef and pork.

U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said U.S. officials might still work out a partial resolution with the two neighbours, adding that they needed to do more on the fentanyl front.

On March 12, Canada said it would impose retaliatory tariffs on U.S. imported goods worth C$29.8 billion ($20 billion) in response to Trump’s steel and aluminium tariffs.

While the two countries are currently exempt from the”Liberation Day” tariffs announced on April 2, they do face a separate set of 25% tariffs on auto imports.

Canada has requested WTO dispute consultations with the U.S. over its imposition of import duties on certain steel and aluminium products, as well as the levies on cars and car parts from Canada.

CHINA: Trump levied 10% tariffs across all Chinese imports into the U.S., effective on February 4, following repeated warnings to Beijing about insufficient measures to halt the flow of illicit drugs into the U.S.

He followed that up with another 10% duty on Chinese goods, effective March 4.

China responded by announcing additional tariffs of 10% to 15% on certain U.S. imports from March 10 and a series of new export restrictions for designated U.S. entities.

Later, it raised complaints about the U.S. tariffs with the WTO.

On April 2, Trump imposed an additional 34% tariff on China, bringing the total new levy to 54%, which prompted the world’s second-biggest economy to retaliate with a duty of 34% on all U.S. goods.

Trump responded that the U.S. would impose an additional 50% tariff on China if Beijing does not withdraw its retaliatory tariffs on the U.S., and said “all talks with China concerning their requested meetings with us will be terminated.”

Washington’s fresh round of tariffs lifted duties on China to an eye-watering 145%, prompting Beijing to jack up levies on U.S. goods by 125% in an intensifying trade war between the world’s two biggest economies.

EUROPE: Trump said the EU and other countries have troubling trade surpluses with the U.S.

He has said the countries’ products will either be subject to tariffs or he will demand they buy more oil and gas from the U.S., even though U.S. gas export capacity is near its limits.

The 27-nation bloc faces 25% import tariffs on steel, aluminium, and cars, as well as broader tariffs of 20% from April 9 for almost all other goods.

Among vulnerable industries is pharmaceuticals, as U.S. firms such as Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer have large plants in Ireland, which is also a major exporter of medical devices.

The European Union said on April 7 it had offered a”zero-for-zero” tariff deal to avert a trade war, with EU ministers agreeing to prioritise negotiations while striking back with targeted countermeasures next week.

The EU on March 12 said it would impose counter-tariffs on 26 billion euros ($28 billion) worth of U.S. goods from next month in response to Trump’s metals tariffs.

The bloc is expected to produce a larger package of countermeasures by the end of April as a response to U.S. car and broader tariffs.

On March 13, Trump threatened to slap a 200% tariff on European wine and spirits in response to the EU plan to impose tariffs on American whiskey and other products next month.

AUTOS: On March 26, Trump unveiled a 25% tariff on imported cars and light trucks.

The 25% levy would be imposed on top of previous duties on imports of finished vehicles starting on April 3.

However, on April 29, he signed a pair of orders to soften the blow of his auto tariffs with a mix of credits and relief from other levies on materials.

In a partial rollback of his tariff policies, the Republican president has granted automakers a two-year window to increase the share of domestic components in vehicles built in the U.S.

METALS: On March 12, Trump increased tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports to 25%, and extended the duties to hundreds of downstream products, from nuts and bolts to bulldozer blades and soda cans.

The U.S. is the world’s largest aluminum importer and the second-largest steel importer, with more than half of those volumes coming from Canada, Mexico and Brazil.

Trump on February 25 ordered a fresh probe into possible new tariffs on copper imports to rebuild U.S. production of the metal critical in electric vehicles, military hardware, semiconductors and a wide range of consumer goods.
